; Thu, 04 Jan 2024 09:50:22 GMT /content/c9afnf98s4qqnm5bah8lgadbsua4u0c2 https://www.economist.com/briefing/2024/01/04/joe-bidens-chances-do-not-look-good-the-democrats-have-no-plan-b美国选举 Brexit? Hah! Lockdowns? Shrug! Can nothing stop London?

I t was not an auspicious time to open a pub in central London.当迈克尔·贝尔本和他的生意 合伙人接管了法灵顿路的鹰号，当时英国正处于经济衰退之中。他们没有被吓倒，从汽车后备箱销售处购买了不匹配的陶器，拆除了水果机和飞镖盘，安装了开放式厨房和黑板菜单。该酒吧于 1991 年 1 月重新开业。

In the decades since, the struggles and success of the Eagle—reputedly Britain's first “gastropub”—have encapsulated those of London itself.起初，它的地中海菜肴很新颖； but as the city's tastes and population diversified, its formula of refined but affordable grub was widely imitated. 2007-09 年的金融危机并未让老鹰队感到不安。它克服了新冠肺炎 (covid-19) 及其破坏性的社交距离规则。贝尔本表示，对于一个一直雇用欧洲移民的场所来说，英国脱欧可能是“一个可怕的问题”。但尚未。

“It's amazing how resilient we are,” he concludes. The same can be said of London. In the early 1990s a city that had seemed to be on the skids was rejuvenated. After shrinking by over a fifth since the second world war, the population began to grow. Enterprising foreigners poured in. The economy boomed, fuelled by financial deregulation, European integration and communism's collapse. By the time it hosted the Olympic games in 2012, London had a fair claim to be the capital of the world.

Cue a perfect storm of woes that threatened to capsize cities in general and London in particular. Already its mercantile heart had been shocked by the financial crisis. Then a cosmopolis that runs on immigration faced the shuttering of Brexit and the pandemic barred tourists from one of the planet's most visited places.

Yet like the Eagle, London is thriving—a hardiness that holds lessons for cities everywhere. Its globalised economy has weathered Britain's exit from the European Union far better than doomsayers had predicted. For all the political bluster on immigration, it remains a magnet for ambitious newcomers. And it is better-placed than many cities to absorb the disruptions of covid-19. Traverse London from south to north and west to east, and you find that its biggest challenges are the results of its dynamism rather than decline. Begin in the south London neighbourhood of Peckham.

A regal woman in ceremonial Yoruba attire rides a horse down Peckham's high street. Youngsters playing basketball and shoppers at west African grocers watch in wonder (with classic London insouciance, some don't bat an eyelid). Adeyemi Michael's short film, recently on show at the South London Gallery in Peckham, honoured the Nigerians who began thronging to this part of the capital in the 1970s, earning it the nickname “Little Lagos”.

Southern crossroads

You can still eat knockout jollof rice at Lolak Afrique, a café just off Peckham's main drag. But the neighbourhood, and London's Nigerian community, are changing. As cocktail bars and sushi restaurants have moved in, the Nigerians have spread out, their numbers falling in Southwark, the borough which includes Peckham, and rising elsewhere. London has never been as ethnically segregated as some American cities; as analysis by Gemma Catney of Queen's University Belfast shows, it has become progressively less so over the past few decades, the black African population dispersing especially fast.

As it spreads, London's Nigerian population is growing. In the past couple of years post-Brexit immigration policies have admitted many more students and workers (largely in health care) from beyond Europe. In the year to June 2023, 141,000 Nigerians moved to Britain, more than the total from the entire EU , to which there is now net emigration.

On December 4th the government announced plans to cut immigration. But so far, at least, the fear that Brexit might stem the flow of migrants to London has not been realised. In one of Brexit's ironies, other arrivals have more than compensated for the shortfall of Europeans. Partly as a result, London's population, which dipped during the pandemic, is nudging 9m and is expected to hit 10m by 2040. Taking into account the inflow of skills and students, says Jonathan Portes of King's College London, Brexit's effect on the city “has if anything been positive”, in terms of immigration, at least. It remains “a roost for every bird”, as Benjamin Disraeli wrote in 1870.

Nor does the latest influx into what was already a spectacularly diverse city seem to have stirred much tension. According to Ipsos, a pollster, Londoners are more than twice as likely as Parisians to say immigrants have had a positive impact on their home town. Suella Braverman, twice forced out as home secretary in Conservative governments, recently claimed multiculturalism has “failed”. She is walking proof of the opposite: a Buddhist brought up in London by parents from Mauritius and Kenya, she found a Jewish husband and rose to one of the highest offices in the land. The London dream, you might call it.

In another widely predicted way, Brexit has indeed bruised London: by damaging the City, an engine of growth already beleaguered by the financial crisis and the rise of other hubs. Yet as at the Eagle, the consequences have, so far, been manageable.

Brexit's overall costs will be felt as much in things that don't happen—internships forgone, romances that never blossom—as in those that do. The same goes for its impact on the City, says William Wright of New Financial, a think-tank. He points to the hundreds of new jobs created in Paris by American investment banks, which in different circumstances would probably have come to London. As for things that have happened: London's share of new listings, and of trade in European equities and derivatives, has dwindled.

Still, relatively few existing jobs have been relocated from the City because of Brexit. The latest estimate by EY , a consultancy, is around 7,000, far lower than the tens of thousands once anticipated. The City will no longer be the default financial centre for Europe, predicts Mr Wright; but because of its status in global financial markets, it is set to remain the dominant hub in Europe. It is big enough to cope.

Besides sheer size, the City and the rest of London enjoy two other advantages in Brexit's aftermath. The first is that they already did lots of business with the world beyond Europe, receiving copious foreign direct investment ( FDI ) from America especially. London has become even more reliant on American investment since Brexit, observes Riccardo Crescenzi of the London School of Economics ( lse ). Worryingly, when downsizing and divestment are included, in 2021 there was a net outflow of foreign capital from both London and Britain for the first time since 1984. Even so, says Professor Crescenzi, London is still the top city in Europe for new FDI projects 。

The other plus is that the industries in which London specialises—not just finance but law, accounting, consulting, the media and higher education—have been less hampered by post-Brexit rules than other sectors. Between 2016 and 2021 London's exports of services grew by 47%, notes Emily Fry of the Resolution Foundation, another think-tank; for the rest of Britain the rise was just 4%. Places that import parts and export goods have suffered more Brexit-related costs and bureaucracy.

The momentum of the tech scene, in particular, is too strong to be “stopped in its tracks”, insists Brent Hoberman, a tech guru and investor. Because of Brexit “we have to be more paranoid” about competition, but, he reckons, London remains the best place to start a tech firm in Europe. American venture capitalists are still keen. The record supports his confidence: London has produced more tech unicorns than its three nearest European rivals—Berlin, Paris and Stockholm—combined.

Unhobbled hub

Its perennial virtues—the time zone, English language and rule of law—are reinforced by the proximity of top universities and an abundance of skills and capital. Babs Ogundeyi, the founder of Kuda, a fintech firm based in London, says savvy local angel investors helped attract more capital. Kuda runs a digital-only bank in Nigeria and a remittance service for Africans in Britain. For all Brexit's hassles, Mr Ogundeyi notes, it has led to closer ties to Africa.

The upshot is another irony of Brexit; you might also call it karma or poetic justice. London, the only region of England that in the referendum of 2016 voted to stay in the EU , has fared better than regions that wanted to leave. For overlapping reasons, it has bounced back faster from the pandemic. Head to north London to see why.

Sally north

On a chilly evening at Arsenal's football stadium, the club's new anthem rings around the ground: “North London for ever/Whatever the weather/These streets are our own.” It is a sentimental but affecting tune, especially after the lockdown months in which spectators were barred. Now the stadium is packed; Gunnersaurus, the team's mascot, is high-fiving young fans. The faithful are loudly outraged by lunging tackles on their hero, the winger Bukayo Saka (he duly scores).

Like the carousing at the Eagle, London's entertainment economy is buoyant again after the deathly doldrums of covid-19. Its seven Premier League football clubs project soft power around the globe. Tourism has almost returned to pre-pandemic levels, boosted by a rise in American visitors. The Society of London Theatre says audiences are up. On some weekends the Tube is busier than in 2019.

All told, London's nimble economy has recovered much more strongly than has the rest of the country's. Like other cities, it faces obstacles in the post-covid world. But it is better equipped for them than many.

Already under pressure from online shopping, some retail districts are struggling—notably Oxford Street, which this year looks somewhat bedraggled beneath its Christmas lights. Along with a rise in rough sleeping, vacant shops have contributed to a dilapidated air in parts of central London. By some accounts, however, the main threat to its pizzazz is Londoners' reluctance to return to the office full-time.

One Triton Square, an office tower a mile from the Eagle, near Regent's Park, is an emblem of this trend. It stands in a snazzy development with all the modish appurtenances of a modern office complex, including a climbing wall and an art gallery. But the building is empty. Lights blink eerily in the dark atrium; the escalators are frozen. Earlier this year Meta, the parent company of Facebook, paid a whopping fee to cancel its lease on the tower before it even moved in.

The ghostly building is not unique. Vacancy rates in commercial property in central London are high, in part because—as elsewhere, only more so—people are loth to kick the working-from-home ( WFH ) habit acquired during the pandemic. A recent survey for the Centre for Cities, also a think-tank, found that, on average, workers in central London were in the office 2.3 days per week, less than other Britons. Of 32 countries surveyed for research by Nick Bloom of Stanford University, British workers stayed home more than any bar Canadians. Taken together, these findings imply Londoners are among the most absent workers anywhere.

Face-to-face interactions are good for productivity, already stalling in London before the pandemic. Low office attendance could in time deter foreign investors. Then again, in a WFH future, London has enticements that other places lack.

A three-days-a-week office will have to look different from the antediluvian sort: more flexible and alluring. Yet networking, transport and entertainment possibilities mean the case for keeping a central-London HQ is stronger than for having a satellite office. Notably, the WFH culture has not led armies of Londoners to retreat beyond striking distance of the workplace. Most inner Londoners who moved home between the summers of 2021 and 2022 circulated around the city, rather than fleeing it.

It has brushed off another crisis that some thought would nobble it: the war in Ukraine and ensuing sanctions on Russia's elite, who had brought joy to London's libel lawyers, estate agents, PR firms and football fans. For all their notoriety and flamboyance, their largesse was always less important than that from China and the Middle East, says Oliver Bullough, author of “Butler to the World”, an exposé of Britain's services to kleptocracy. In any case, plenty of other high-rollers still call London home, or one of them. (For an Ozymandian monument to London's indulgence of oligarchs, stroll west from Harrods and look out for a disused Tube station. In 2014 the government sold it for £53m—$87m at the time—to Dmitry Firtash, a Ukrainian tycoon wanted in America on charges of alleged corruption, which he denies.)

London, after all, has absorbed all manner of shocks in its 2,000-year history. Its most precarious period, considers Tony Travers of the lse , came after the Romans left in the fifth century AD . The Black Death killed much of its population in the 1340s; the Great Fire of 1666 razed swathes of it. A port city that adapted to the decline of its port, it was also an imperial capital that acclimatised to the loss of empire. It defied the Blitz of 1940-41—when, rather than sheltering in the Tube as urban myth has it, most Londoners simply slept at home.

That phlegmatism is one of London's abiding traits. Its biggest worries now may not be external threats but the repercussions of success. Moscow, Paris, Seoul, Tokyo: other cities dominate both the politics and economies of their country. Even so, London stands out for its grip on government, finance, media and the arts (worlds that collide at the Eagle, a watering hole for moneymen and media types and home to an art gallery). Equally glaring are the differences in the demography and outlook of Londoners and their compatriots.

At the last count, disposable household income per person was 43% higher in London than in the country as a whole. Londoners are younger, more left-wing and far more diverse: ethnic minorities account for 46% of residents, over double the proportion in England and Wales. Two-fifths of Londoners were born abroad. Contrary to its reputation in the shires as a latter-day Gomorrah, on average London is slightly more socially conservative and less boozy than other regions.

For that, thank its immigrants, many of whom are devout. They have also helped raise standards in London's schools, which this century have been transformed from the worst-performing of any English region to the best. For a close-up look at that phenomenon, go west.

Known as “Little India”, the western suburb of Southall is studded with Punjabi and Afghan restaurants, mosques and Sikh temples. Nathan Walters, head of the local Featherstone High School, says 85% of its pupils use another language at home. Almost a third receive free school meals (a standard measure of poverty). Whether or not they speak English themselves, parents are “unfailingly positive” about education; results far outstrip the national average. Proximity to opportunity is a motivation, says Mr Walters. Pupils “can almost see it from their bedroom windows”.

London's dominance, and voracity for people and capital, have been concerns for centuries. Over 400 years ago King James I griped, “Soon, London will be all England.” In the 19th century it was dubbed “the great wen” (cyst). These days polling finds other Britons view it as crowded and expensive and its denizens as arrogant and insular. Many think it is favoured by policymakers and the exchequer, though it contributes far more than it gets back. London's net fiscal contribution per head is over £4,000.

That sort of resentment has fed populism across the West. In Britain it coloured the Brexit referendum. Yet since then, the divide—in wealth, diversity and opportunity—has grown (see chart 1).

In its bid to narrow the gaps, the current government, like its predecessors, has recycled failed ideas. As a recent parliamentary report noted, for instance, schemes to shift civil-service jobs to the regions are reliably launched every ten to 15 years. Often such efforts involve constraining London's growth in hope of diverting it elsewhere. A good example was a misguided rule of 1964 (since discarded) that in effect banned new office developments in central London.

Too often, policies have corseted the capital without boosting other places—and have wound up punishing everyone. The other big cost of London's appeal has proved just as hard to tackle. This distress cry comes from inside the house.

“Affordable housing isn't always as nice as this,” a resident of McGrath Road says with droll London understatement. Home, for her, is one of 26 houses in a beguiling development in Stratford, in the east London borough of Newham.这些单元坐落在不漂亮的 20 世纪庄园中，其中一些是公共住房，看起来像一座摩尔式城堡，有塔楼和垛口，但也有欢迎的拱门、阳台和绿树成荫的中央庭院。走上铁轨，你会看到闪闪发光的塔楼，它们是奥运会刺激的复兴的一部分。

麦格拉斯路的建筑师彼得·巴伯表示，我们可以从北非和中东的紧凑型城市中学到很多东西。他回忆说，纽汉姆市议会最初期望设计一座公寓楼。相反，他效仿了乔治亚风格的露台，这种露台是伦敦高效住房的巅峰之作，但又具有独特的风格。

道路堵塞、空气污染、通勤时间长且昂贵、警察队伍信誉不佳——伦敦不可避免地患有许多大城市的弊病。与同胞相比，伦敦人的社区归属感较低；正如在喧嚣中常见的那样，生活会感到孤独和原子化。 （查尔斯·狄更斯写道：“奇怪的是，一个人可能在伦敦生活和死亡，却很少有人注意到。”） 但最尖锐、最持久的问题是住房的稀缺性和成本——而这一问题在东区最为尖锐、最顽固。

定向压缩

在维多利亚时代晚期，东区被称为“饥饿的帝国”和“可怕的夜晚之城”。如今，纽汉姆的过度拥挤程度是该市的两倍，而其本身则是全国平均水平的两倍多。造成短缺的根本原因是几十年来未能提供足够的新住房，也未能像巴伯先生那样富有想象力地利用空间。

结果既不可避免又令人震惊。美国政治战略家詹姆斯·卡维尔曾开玩笑说，他希望转世成为债券市场，因为那样他就可以恐吓所有人。另一个不错的选择是回归伦敦房价：也许只有这座城市厚颜无耻的狐狸才能与它的坚不可摧相媲美。诚然，持续二十年的金融驱动的繁荣最近已经趋于平缓，但仍处于一个令人眼花缭乱的平台期。

2020 年，首都的平均房屋售价是平均收入的 13 倍以上，几乎是二十年前的两倍（见图 2）。 Eagle 附近的两居室公寓售价约为 100 万英镑。与此同时，自 1981 年以来，居住在公共住房中的伦敦人比例已从三分之一以上下降到五分之一。私营部门的租金飙升：2022 年，租金中位数为收入中位数的 35%。正如伦敦国王学院的杰克·布朗所说，这座城市“从未如此大或如此昂贵”。

所有这些都意味着伦敦人对富裕的看法是不完整的。这是一个富裕的城市，但也有很多穷人。住房成本和贫困率因素高于英格兰其他地区。住在临时住所的伦敦家庭数量是全国家庭数量的八倍。最富裕的十分之一的收入几乎是最贫困人口的十倍。由于伦敦的经济地理异常一体化，贫困家庭和富裕家庭比巴黎或纽约更加紧密地联系在一起，大街上的英镑商店毗邻手工面包店。

特拉弗斯教授指出，对伦敦拥挤程度的抱怨，回想起一个老笑话：餐馆太拥挤了，没有人愿意再去那里了。尽管如此，这场大流行可能会为这个古老的问题找到解决方案。在一个写字楼供应过剩而住宅短缺的地方，在可能的情况下，将商业建筑改造成住宅建筑是有意义的。在混合工作时代，现在比以往任何时候都更需要从现有的通勤走廊开始，在“绿化带”的一些受保护土地上进行建设。

类似的事情发生在过去的危机之后。克里斯托弗·雷恩在大火的灰烬中重新构想了这座城市。理想主义的城市规划者在闪电战的废墟中再次这样做了。过去几年和过去两千年的证据表明，伦敦——世界上最伟大的城市之一，也许也是最具弹性的城市——将找到一种应对和繁荣的方法。 ■

; Thu, 14 Dec 2023 14:06:18 GMT /内容/0uj96uc0a8884cmmdc2d1p9f3jire2kt https://www.economist.com/briefing/2023/12/14/brexit-hah-lockdowns-shrug-can-nothing-stop-london英国 Despite the war in Gaza, talk of a two-state solution persists

B确实是残酷和令人痛苦的，但也许以色列和哈马斯之间的战争也可能是一个机会。至少美国总统是这么认为的。尽管他支持以色列自卫的权利，但他认为这场战斗应该给以色列人和巴勒斯坦人敲响警钟。他在接受电视采访时表示：“现在时机已经成熟，双方应该认识到，他们所走的道路不会为其人民带来繁荣和安全。”

在这个例子中，总统是大约 15 年前刚刚就职的巴拉克·奥巴马 (Barack Obama)。但今天也可能是乔·拜登。历史在中东不断重演。加沙战争再次引发了和平讨论，但考虑到 10 月 7 日以色列对加沙的袭击导致 1,200 多名以色列人遭到屠杀，以及随后约 16,000 名巴勒斯坦人被杀害，和平讨论似乎有些牵强。自 1948 年以色列建国以来，圣地从未经历过如此多的流血事件。和平似乎从未如此遥远。

阅读我们对以色列和哈马斯之间战争的所有报道。

尽管如此，拜登还是希望它能够出现。 “当这场危机结束后，必须对接下来的情况有一个愿景，我们认为这必须是两国解决方案，”他在十月份表示。 11 月在巴林举行的一次会议上，一位又一位阿拉伯官员发出了类似的信息。阿拉伯联合酋长国（ UAE ）总统顾问安瓦尔·加尔加什（Anwar Gargash）表示：“我们需要回到两国解决方案，回到以色列和巴勒斯坦并存的国家。”

一些人认为此类言论只是一块遮羞布，旨在消除人们对西方支持以色列以及阿拉伯国家在可怕的战争中无所作为的疑虑。毕竟，以色列和巴勒斯坦之间30年的和平进程充满了失败。如果至少没有三项根本性的改变，谈判的重启从一开始就注定会失败。首先是新的领导层。当前加沙战争双方的政党正是30年前竭力破坏新生和平进程的政党。他们必须走。接下来是努力让谈判变得可信：双方都更加怀疑对方的诚意。最后，双方都需要激励才能达成协议。巴勒斯坦人需要感到他们的国家是可行的，以色列人需要感到他们的国家是安全的。

两国解决方案以这样或那样的形式已经存在了近一个世纪。 1947年，联合国通过了一项巴勒斯坦分治计划，该计划将创建两个国家，一个阿拉伯国家，一个犹太国家，并由国际社会控制耶路撒冷。阿拉伯国家拒绝了，以色列宣布独立，其邻国迅速入侵。

经过数十年的冲突，以色列人和巴勒斯坦人于 1991 年在马德里举行的和平会议上开始谈判。随后于 1993 年达成了奥斯陆协议，该协议规定了建立巴勒斯坦国的五年期限，同时建立了巴勒斯坦权力机构 ( PA ) ，一个类似的政府，尽管权力和管辖权有限，仅对部分被占领土进行管辖。一系列失败接踵而至：戴维营和塔巴峰会、布什政府的“和平路线图”、奥巴马的外交。上一次直接谈判于 2014 年破裂，此后再也没有恢复过。

遥不可及却又坚不可摧

一直以来，两国解决方案的轮廓几乎没有变化。加沙和约旦河西岸将建立一个巴勒斯坦国——约占历史上巴勒斯坦面积的 22%——其首都位于东耶路撒冷。以色列将在约旦河西岸保留一些定居点，以换取领土交换，并撤离其他定居点。象征性数量的难民将被允许返回以色列，更多的难民将被允许返回巴勒斯坦。

这个想法曾经很流行，但许多人失去了信心。即使在 10 月 7 日之前，也只有大约三分之一的巴勒斯坦人和以色列犹太人支持两国解决方案，低于五年前的近一半（见图表）。 “每一个失败的进程都有一个代价，”以色列政治家西蒙·佩雷斯的外交政策顾问尼姆罗德·诺维克说。 “这强化了这是不可能做到的错误结论。”自 10 月 7 日以来，以色列对任何形式的和平谈判的支持都大幅下降。

尽管幻灭，但没有明确的选择。民意调查显示，以色列人和巴勒斯坦人对于如何结束冲突存在分歧。一些人希望有一个“单一国家解决方案”，让他们生活在一个享有平等权利的国家。其他人支持种族隔离或种族清洗（当然，他们不同意这种做法的受害者是谁）。

这些都是无用的。 10 月 7 日的事件打破了现状。驱逐或歧视是令人憎恶的。一国解决方案可能听起来合理，但实际上行不通：大多数以色列人和巴勒斯坦人拒绝这个想法。

剩下两个状态。问题在于，这个解决方案需要双方做出巨大牺牲。以色列人将不得不放弃土地，而巴勒斯坦人则必须放弃自 1948 年以来失去的大部分土地。双方领导人都需要向持怀疑态度的公众兜售这些让步。但双方都没有这样的领导人。

以色列有本雅明·内塔尼亚胡，他的整个职业生涯都在努力阻止巴勒斯坦国的出现。为了讨好奥巴马，他确实在 2009 年巴伊兰大学的一次演讲中支持了两国解决方案，尽管六年后他宣称中东已经发生了变化，他的演讲“无关紧要”。他的利库德集团通过了反对巴勒斯坦建国的决议。以色列公共广播公司 Kan 在 11 月报道称，内塔尼亚胡先生会见了利库德集团的后座议员，恳求他的政治生存。他说：“战后，我是唯一能够阻止加沙、朱迪亚和撒玛利亚建立巴勒斯坦国的人。”他用的是约旦河西岸的希伯来语名称。

但内塔尼亚胡先生的日子已经屈指可数了。根据 11 月份公布的民意调查显示，大多数以色列人希望他下台——76% 的人希望他下台。调查显示，如果举行选举，他的利库德集团将失去其目前在议会 120 名议员中拥有的 32 个席位中的一半左右。

接替内塔尼亚胡先生的领跑者是前陆军参谋长本尼·甘茨 (Benny Gantz)，他于 10 月份不情愿地加入了内塔尼亚胡先生的战时内阁。他的中右翼民族团结党在民调中大幅领先。他正在成为以色列难以驾驭的政治中的一个罕见人物：一个团结的人物。

部分原因在于他对两国解决方案的模糊立场。他在公开场合对此鲜有提及。该党的官方立场是含糊其辞地呼吁“与巴勒斯坦人分离”，但没有详细说明如何实现这一目标。与甘茨关系密切的消息人士称，他无意提供更具体的信息。他们说，这样做对内塔尼亚胡先生有利。巴勒斯坦建国问题是一个棘手问题，因此甘茨先生将尽力避免这个问题，以吸引选民远离总理。

“在本尼与美国人的谈话中，他说我们应该停止在新情况下使用旧词，”一名助手说。换句话说，他愿意讨论两国解决方案的某种形式，但对使用这个不光彩的术语持谨慎态度。在该党进行的调查中，大多数以色列人赞成用“两个独立实体”等其他术语描述两国解决方案。

如果甘茨先生寻求对两国解决方案进行一些修改，他将面临政治障碍。他所在的政党包括反对这一举措的鹰派议员。 “甘茨那里有一些非常非常右翼的人，”以色列智库肖雷什研究所的丹·本·大卫说。对于他的一些潜在的联盟伙伴以及在过去几十年里转向右翼的以色列公众来说也是如此。

巴勒斯坦政治看起来更加令人生畏。对于哈马斯来说，和平进程是不可想象的，因为哈马斯花了三十年的时间来搅局。它发起了一场自杀式爆炸运动，以破坏奥斯陆协议，然后在巴勒斯坦人第二次起义或起义期间持续发动袭击，使一代以色列人对和平理念产生了不满。

巴勒斯坦总统马哈茂德·阿巴斯和他的民族主义法塔赫政党都支持两国解决方案。但他已经 88 岁了，很快将开始本应四年任期的第 20 个年头。很少有巴勒斯坦人（或以色列人）认为他有合法性或智慧来领导认真推动和平。一名以色列官员表示，“他处于一个妄想泡沫之中，周围都是三四个非常有权势的唯唯诺诺的人”，阿巴斯的许多前同事也有同样的评价。

白宫正在考虑让技术官僚前总理、国际货币基金组织前官员萨拉姆·法耶兹重返原来的工作岗位。就连阿拉伯官员现在也私下表示，他们希望改变巴勒斯坦领导层。沙特正在推动阿巴斯的得力助手侯赛因·谢赫接替总统。阿联酋希望看到前法塔赫安全负责人穆罕默德·达赫兰（Muhammad Dahlan）发挥作用，过去十年他一直流亡在阿布扎比。它们都会被以色列接受——但也许不会被巴勒斯坦人接受。民意调查显示他们的受欢迎程度只有个位数。

看似合理但不可行

另一个选择是法塔赫领导人马尔万·巴尔古提（Marwan Barghouti），他因策划袭击以色列平民而在以色列服刑五次无期徒刑。 （他拒绝进行辩护，谴责审判是非法的。）一些人希望他能成为巴勒斯坦人纳尔逊·曼德拉（Nelson Mandela），出狱后团结分裂的运动并与以色列进行谈判。他经常被评为最受欢迎的巴勒斯坦领导人，但这主要是因为他已经淡出了公众视线数十年，而当时法塔赫正陷入腐败和衰老。即使以色列允许他出境，也不清楚他的领导人能力如何。

美国和阿拉伯官员一直在推动巴勒斯坦选举。不过，至少在约旦河西岸，这可能会为哈马斯的残余势力带来胜利，巴勒斯坦人认为哈马斯是唯一愿意对抗以色列的政党。法塔赫要想重新获得民众的支持，需要做两件事。一是遏制其成员猖獗的腐败行为（当被问及巴勒斯坦权力机构要解决的最紧迫问题时，更多的巴勒斯坦人提到腐败而不是占领）。另一个是表明非暴力方法可以产生结果。 “他们必须让哈马斯变得无效，”来自加沙的巴勒斯坦学者哈利勒·萨耶说。 “人们必须看到哈马斯并没有真正做任何好事。”

这需要以色列做出让步，这就引出了第二个问题：如何让谈判变得可信。经过几十年的失败，以色列人和巴勒斯坦人都会持怀疑态度。不过，对于以色列人来说，这几十年仍然是美好的：它们恰逢经济繁荣、长期相对和平以及与阿拉伯国家关系迅速发展。对于巴勒斯坦人来说，他们带来的只是加深的绝望。 “独立巴勒斯坦国的整个计划正在成为过去的一部分，”巴勒斯坦前部长加桑·哈提卜说。以色列有责任消除这种看法。

诺维克先生是以色列安全司令部的成员，该组织由退休安全官员组成，主张两国解决方案。他提供了以色列可以采取的一系列步骤，以表明新的承诺。它可能会缩小C区，即以色列完全控制的西岸三分之二的地区，并扩大B区，巴勒斯坦权力机构在该区拥有民事事务权，但无安全权。 （巴勒斯坦权力机构完全控制的A区甚至更小：参见地图。）它可以停止拆除C区无证房屋，因为它拒绝向巴勒斯坦人发放建筑许可证（通常每年发放十个或更少）。它可以减少军队对巴勒斯坦城市的袭击。

然而，对于巴勒斯坦人来说，这些步骤还远远不够。稍微扩大B区很难成为法塔赫可以向可疑公众兜售的一项响亮成就。 “我们为了一个国家已经等待了 30 年，”一位外交官说道。 “我们不需要一些建筑许可证。”毕竟，《奥斯陆协议》因渐进主义而被毁：双方需要通过象征性举措建立信任，然后才能就更实质性的步骤达成一致。

当被问及什么才是更严肃的姿态时，几位巴勒斯坦分析人士指出了被占领的约旦河西岸的定居点，这里居住着约 465,000 名以色列人。他们说，仅仅冻结新建筑是不够的；以前曾尝试过这种做法，包括奥巴马领导下的尝试。以色列应该更进一步，拆除一些在和平协议中必须放弃的定居点。这既可以建立信心，又可以推进最终地位协议。在以色列，这在政治上似乎也是不可能的，特别是在 10 月 7 日之后，因为这将被视为奖励一场屠杀。

经过数十年的拖延，如果没有美国的压力，以色列不太可能做出任何重大姿态。 “除非以色列体系确实认为朝这个方向前进是有代价的，否则我看不出如何为不同的政治腾出一些空间，”以色列前谈判代表丹尼尔·利维(Daniel Levy)表示。一位阿拉伯外交官表示，这种压力最初也应该针对定居者：“美国需要采取强硬措施。”

12月6日，美国宣布将对袭击巴勒斯坦人及其财产的暴力定居者实施签证禁令。这是前所未有的一步，但也具有象征意义。出于意识形态动机的定居者不太可能因签证禁令而被劝退。无论如何，他们中的一些人是不能被禁止的：他们是美国公民。

美国对定居点的挤压要想取得成功，就需要将以色列也包括在内。国际法规定以色列军队有义务保护被占领土上的巴勒斯坦人，但以色列军队经常在定居者发动袭击时袖手旁观。如果继续允许（有时甚至怂恿）此类暴力，美国可能会威胁削减军事援助。对于巴勒斯坦人和阿拉伯世界来说，这将是一个明确的信号，表明美国认真地试图扮演一个不那么有偏见的角色。但在选举年，或者如果唐纳德·特朗普 (Donald Trump) 在 2024 年赢得总统宝座，这样的威胁是很难想象的。不过，如果拜登获得连任，这样的举动将受到党内进步派的欢迎。

除了威胁之外，美国及其合作伙伴还必须提供激励措施。对于巴勒斯坦人来说，这些可能主要是财务方面的。最紧迫的问题是如何重建支离破碎的加沙，其费用轻而易举就达到数百亿美元。富裕的海湾国家愿意做出贡献，但前提是加沙成为巴勒斯坦国的一部分，并且它们的投资不太可能再次被炸毁。

与此同时，海湾国家可以帮助缓解以色列的安全担忧。奥斯陆进程开始时，只有一个阿拉伯国家埃及与以色列建立了外交关系。如今，其中六个已加入，而且沙特阿拉伯似乎也愿意加入该俱乐部。与阿拉伯世界建立正常关系的前景似乎是真实的，这是过去几十年从未有过的。不仅结束与巴勒斯坦人的冲突，而且结束与整个地区的冲突应该是一个强有力的诱因。

本月早些时候在卡塔尔举行的一次会议上，海湾国家讨论了战后加沙的计划。他们决心与约旦、埃及和西方大国合作，组建国际联盟，推动两国解决方案。阿拉伯国家将要求巴勒斯坦权力机构选择新的领导人，而美国将向以色列施压。

但即使海湾国家承认以色列，伊朗支持的激进组织（例如黎巴嫩真主党或也门胡塞武装）也不会这样做。 “我们必须让伊朗加入，”一位来自海湾地区的外交官表示。当被问及这是否现实时，他表示反对。几十年来，对以色列的敌意一直是伊斯兰共和国意识形态的核心原则。巴勒斯坦国的建立可能不会在一夜之间将他们变成犹太复国主义者。

熟悉但不确定

那么，风险就是历史再次重演。新一批领导人可能会口头上支持两国解决方案。以色列可能会软化对巴勒斯坦权力机构的敌意并做出一些让步。海湾国家将承诺提供资金和认可。但所提出的协议从根本上来说与以前是一样的——这一协议遭到了更为乐观的一代以色列人和巴勒斯坦人的拒绝。

近年来，双方知识分子都开始呼吁更多的创造性思维。一种想法是建立一个联盟，其中既有犹太人又有巴勒斯坦实体。一方的公民有权在另一方生活和工作。这个想法是为了降低如此小块土地如何瓜分的重要性，并让双方对对方的稳定更加感兴趣。

这个想法比标准的两国蓝图面临更多的障碍，但新颖的概念有一个优点。 “以色列受益于不严肃的国际做法，这种做法只是说，回到两国谈判，”利维先生说。这些谈判常常成为目的而不是手段，尽管到目前为止已经几乎没有什么可谈判的了：一切都已经被无休止地讨论过。过去几个月的事件表明现状是难以维持的。改变是不可避免的。唯一的问题是它将采取什么形式。 ■

; Thu, 07 Dec 2023 10:47:40 GMT /内容/of9f959q94l39u3lapp6p2hjtssbdphq https://www.economist.com/briefing/2023/12/07/尽管-the-war-in-gaza-talk-of-a-two-state-solution-persists以色列 How Putin is reshaping Russia to keep his war-machine running

尽管面临战争和制裁，11月初，经过翻修的苏联时代“国民经济成就展览”在莫斯科重新开幕。原版于 1939 年落成，就在德国和俄罗斯入侵波兰前几周，它掩盖了前几年的饥荒和恐怖。相反，展览颂扬了苏联科学的奇迹和集体化的优点；一个特殊的冰淇淋大厅向群众分发美食，一座 25 米高的斯大林雕像慷慨地俯视着下方。数百万人在独裁者与过去的“大决裂”中丧生，俄罗斯的经济和社会被彻底重塑，但这一切都被描述为纯粹的进步。

阅读我们最近对乌克兰战争的更多报道

这与今天的翻修工程有着类似的故事，一条未来派的、布满屏幕的隧道向游客展示了弗拉基米尔·普京 (Vladimir Putin) 领导下的过去 20 年的辉煌。一个庆祝俄罗斯地区的展馆以顿涅茨克、赫尔松、卢甘斯克和扎波罗热为特色，俄罗斯军队目前正试图从乌克兰夺取这四个省份。持续流血的唯一迹象是一朵由弹片碎片组成的花朵。 1945年以来欧洲最大规模战争的爆发、俄罗斯境内重新建立警察国家以及后苏联时期早期改革和西化趋势的彻底逆转都不见踪影。

这与战争初期的震惊和混乱截然不同，当时卢布暴跌，数十万人逃离该国，抗议活动震撼了俄罗斯的城市。此后，普京凭借高油价成功稳定了经济，并通过严厉镇压压制了异议。这使他能够保留精英阶层的忠诚，而精英阶层反过来又帮助国家适应变化。然而，新的均衡是不稳定的，尤其是经济和征兵问题，有可能引发进一步的动荡。

不羁的羊

从表面上看，大多数俄罗斯人都温顺地接受了乌克兰战争即将过去两年的事实。三分之二的人告诉民意调查专家俄罗斯菲尔德，该国正在朝着正确的方向前进，超过一半的人表示乌克兰战争进展顺利。 “我知道社会是完全墨守成规的，但我仍然没想到心理适应的程度如此令人难以置信。人们只是把自己封闭起来，试图过上平常的生活，”学者纳拉利亚·祖巴列维奇(Nalalya Zubarevich)在最近的一次采访中表示。

公开抗议很少见，原因显而易见。 11 月 16 日，艺术家兼活动家亚历山德拉·斯科奇连科 (Alexandra Skochilenko) 因用反战信息替换圣彼得堡一家超市的价格标签而被判入狱七年。 （其中写道：“我的曾祖父参加第二次世界大战并不是为了让俄罗斯成为法西斯国家并攻击乌克兰。”）受到迫害的不仅仅是和平主义者：至少有一位极端民族主义持不同政见者伊戈尔·吉尔金（Igor Girkin）、退役军人兼博客作者，因抱怨普京的战斗不够有力而被判入狱。

但仅仅因为大多数俄罗斯人接受了战争并不意味着他们对战争充满热情。一部仓促炮制的关于乌克兰卑鄙“法西斯分子”的宣传片，耗资 200 万美元制作，却惨遭失败，票房仅 15 万美元。尽管俄罗斯菲尔德民意调查的受访者声称支持战争，但他们坚决反对进一步的动员，即使普京本人也这么呼吁。 10 月，大多数受访者在战争期间首次表示支持和平谈判而不是继续战斗（见图 1）。整整 74% 的人表示，他们很高兴普京先生立即签署和平协议。

也许并不奇怪，年轻人越年轻，他们从社交媒体而不是国营电视上获取的新闻越多，他们对战争的怀疑就越多。然而，更引人注目的是，人们越富有、受教育程度越高，他们就越支持（见图 2）。正如一位匿名的俄罗斯学者最近在在线出版物《Meduza》上发表的一篇文章中所解释的那样，有一大批官僚和商人通过庇护获得了地位，他们将维护政权并保护它。 “他们的数量有数百万人，他们已经融入了军事侵略的道德经济，”这位学者写道。

在某种程度上，这些人像其他人一样因恐惧而保持一致。在战争的头几个月里，国有企业商人和经理的一系列神秘死亡有助于灌输忠诚。俄罗斯最大的私营石油公司卢克石油公司(Lukoil)发表呼吁停火的声明几个月后，该公司董事长从莫斯科一家医院的窗户坠落身亡。西方对寡头的制裁也有助于保持有钱阶层的参与。

把目光移开

但公务员和商人也有压制顾忌和运作制度的长期经验。许多人已经从苏联官僚机构平稳过渡。 “驱动他们的不是意识形态，而是对公司的忠诚，无论是央行还是财政部，”一直在调查俄罗斯技术官僚的米哈伊尔·科明说。他们将保持国家之船继续航行的任务视为职业挑战，而不是道德困境。

44 岁的数字化转型部长 Maksut Shadaev 就是一个很好的例子。他于 20 世纪 90 年代在私营IT公司工作，之后加入政府，帮助建立一个时尚、用户友好的门户网站和移动应用程序，使公民能够获得预约医生和儿童入学等公共服务。他现在正在利用同样的技能建立一个被称为“数字古拉格”的系统——一个全面的登记册，帮助追踪有资格参加选秀的男性。

出于同样的原因，俄罗斯企业帮助稳定经济并不是出于对国家的任何感情，而是因为它们擅长应对环境中巨大的、意外的、往往是任意的变化。哈佛大学的安德烈·雅科夫列夫(Andrei Yakovlev)对俄罗斯企业家进行了一项调查，他表示，经历过多次金融危机并与掠夺性官僚不断斗争的他们非常重视为最坏的情况做准备。与此同时，西方进口品的消失和西方公司的倒闭为俄罗斯公司开辟了新的利基市场。与此同时，央行实施的资本管制让他们别无选择，只能投资俄罗斯。政府提供了贷款，甚至命令官僚不要骚扰他们。

当然，大量石油美元在经济中流动是有帮助的。战争第一年，俄罗斯获得了 5900 亿美元的出口收入，其中大部分来自石油和天然气。根据专家网络 Re: Russia 的计算，这一数字比过去十年的年平均水平高出 1600 亿美元。第二年，收入仍应高于平均水平约 600 亿美元。回复：俄罗斯认为，战争每年至少花费 1000 亿美元，因此来自石油的额外收入足以支付战争的大部分费用。

去年政府预算增加了26%，明年还将再增加16%。明年国防开支将几乎翻倍，达到GDP的 6%——这是自苏联解体以来的最高水平。它现在占所有政府支出的三分之一。与此同时，健康和教育支出的实际支出正在下降。正如财政部长安东·西卢阿诺夫 (Anton Siluanov) 最近宣称的那样：“主要重点是确保我们的胜利。军队、防御能力、武装部队、战士——前线所需的一切、胜利所需的一切都在预算中。”

如此大手笔的支出不可能无限期地持续下去。央行正在努力抑制通胀上升，今年第三季度通胀年化率达到12%。它已将利率提高至15%。与此同时，当局正在迫使出口商将其收入兑换成卢布，以避免卢布进一步贬值，从而加剧通货膨胀。 Russian Field 的数据显示，约 43% 的俄罗斯人预计未来一两年经济状况会恶化，而只有 21% 的人预计经济状况会改善。

然而，目前存在着大量财富，特别是在经济的某些领域和俄罗斯社会的某些领域。 “与石油不同，枪支推动工业增长，”智囊团卡内基俄罗斯欧亚中心的亚历山德拉·普罗科彭科（Alexandra Prokopenko）和帕维尔·鲁津（Pavel Luzin）认为。在靠近战区或拥有大量军火工厂的地区，建筑业、消费和服务业正在增长。在远东地区，由于与欧洲的联系已经萎缩，因此对基础设施进行了大量投资，以扩大与亚洲的贸易。

莫斯科和圣彼得堡并没有从新秩序中受益太多，但萧条的工业地区——普京的心脏地带——却比多年来生活得更好。伊热夫斯克是一座靠近乌拉尔山脉的贫困城市，生产枪支、导弹和电子战设备，自战争开始以来，平均工资上涨了 25%。一家有机超市 VkusVill 和一家泛亚洲餐厅 Royal Rolls 最近开业。在前线军区总部顿河畔罗斯托夫，餐饮业的营业额增长了77%。 “很多胃口很好的男人已经到达那里，”祖巴列维奇女士说。

俄罗斯广阔而贫穷的内陆地区也受益于当局为招募更多新兵而挥舞的现金。志愿人员每月工资约为195,000卢布，是伊热夫斯克新增加的平均工资的四倍，入伍时还可获得195,000卢布的一次性奖金。战争中阵亡者的家属也能获得丰厚的赔偿。华沙波兰高级研究所的俄罗斯经济学家弗拉季斯拉夫·伊诺泽姆采夫(Vladislav Inozemtsev)估计，一名服役五个月后阵亡的士兵的家人将总共获得约1500万卢布，包括工资和补偿。一个俄罗斯男人平均需要 30 年才能赚到这么多钱。俄罗斯男性的预期寿命只有 65 岁。伊诺泽姆采夫表示，普京政权正试图将被杀变成一种经济上理性的选择。

尽管如此，俄罗斯似乎存在人力资源问题。一年前宣布的强制动员——这是第二次世界大战以来的第一次——引起了恐慌和愤怒。征兵委员会被纵火焚烧，数十万年轻人逃离该国或躲藏在俄罗斯境内。随后被征召入伍的人仍留在前线，尽管他们承诺只服役六个月。这引发了一场由他们的妻子和母亲领导的抗议运动，名为“Voina Zaebala” （被战争搞砸了）。 “我们生孩子不是为了让孩子被杀，”一位焦躁的母亲在社交媒体上广泛传播的视频中抱怨道。

警方不仅在大力搜寻逃兵，而且也在搜寻来自中亚的移民，他们似乎正在强行将他们强行拉入兵役。他们最近突袭了俄罗斯最大在线零售商 Wildberry 的仓库，导致其服务停止。学生宿舍也经常遭到袭击。

与此同时，俄罗斯议会杜马正在准备进行更多轮的动员。征兵的最高年龄从27岁提高到30岁。退伍军人的预备役期限延长了五年，初级军官的预备役期限延长至 60 年。法律已修改，要求雇主将其员工送去服兵役。正如杜马国防委员会主席安德烈·卡尔托波洛夫（Andrei Kartopolov）所解释的那样：“这部法律是为一场大战、为全民总动员而制定的。你已经可以闻到空气中那场大战的味道了。”

但人力短缺并不是军队的唯一问题。 《俄罗斯军事改革与军国主义》一书的作者亚历山大·戈尔茨认为，俄罗斯还缺乏初级军官、训练能力和装备。较高的军费支出很可能是极其低效的。俄罗斯军火工业的腐败是出了名的：一些人估计回扣使采购成本翻了一番。它还缺乏熟练劳动力。副总理尤里·鲍里索夫 (Yuri Borisov) 表示，还需要 40 万名工程师、 IT专家和管理人员。

有人说要加强国家对经济的控制，以支持战争。负责军事采购的副总理丹尼斯·曼图罗夫表示，国防工业可能必须重新引入国家规划。 “我们正在谈论战争条件下的经济安全……让我们走上我们经济主要部门国有化的道路，”反腐败机构负责人、普京先生的大学同学亚历山大·巴斯特里金(Alexander Bastrykin)最近表示。 2023 年，有 18 家大公司被国有化，其中许多公司是以将被掠夺的财产归还给国家的名义。总检察长向普京先生报告说，法院已审理了 24,000 起涉及国家财产损失的案件。

国有企业在俄罗斯人的生活中发挥着越来越大、越来越多样化的作用。例如，俄罗斯国有天然气垄断企业俄罗斯天然气工业股份公司(Gazprom)就拥有多家媒体。它还为多个军事旅配备人员、装备和资金。国有石油巨头俄罗斯石油公司建造船舶并监督人类基因组欧亚变体的研究项目。

监管这些庞大帝国的官僚往往本身就是商人，利益重叠。例如，曼图罗夫是国有国防集团 Rostec 的董事会成员。 Rostec 的董事长是谢尔盖·切梅佐夫 (Sergei Chemezov)，他是前克格勃特工，曾在东德与普京一起工作。切梅沃兹和曼图罗夫的家族共同拥有港口、酒店、豪华房产和葡萄园以及其他投资。

普京的朋友和同事的子女在工业界和政府中担任重要职务是一种越来越常见的模式。农业部长德米特里·帕特鲁舍夫是国家安全委员会秘书尼古拉·帕特鲁舍夫的儿子。普京先生的女儿叶卡捷琳娜·吉霍诺娃 (Ekaterina Tikhonova) 担任商业游说团体进口替代委员会主席。 VKontakte 是俄罗斯最大的社交媒体平台，由多家国有公司部分拥有，由普京副幕僚长的儿子和一位富商的曾侄子共同运营，据说这位富商是普京的成员之一。普京最亲密的心腹和入侵乌克兰的鼓吹者。

俄罗斯在战争开始时决定禁止 Facebook 和 Instagram，使得 VKontakte 的用户在短短几周内增加了 400 万。它现在的渗透率为 75%，被认为受到安全部门的密切监控，并且有助于传播支持战争的信息。 “这是普京的梦想和理想模式：一切都集中在一个地方，由孩子们在克格勃的监督下管理，”Re: Russia 的创始人基里尔·罗戈夫 (Kirill Rogov) 说道。

犯罪英雄

为了证明他重建俄罗斯经济的合理性，并解释他在军事上缺乏成功的原因，普京将这场战争重新定义为与西方的战争，而不是与乌克兰的战争，在这场战争中，乌克兰只是用来打击俄罗斯的“攻城槌”。新的历史教科书向学生解释说，俄罗斯一直并将永远处于与西方的战争状态。这种叙述让普京将日常活动描述为一种胜利。他在入侵周年纪念日的演讲中夸口说：“让俄罗斯公司成功开拓市场是一场胜利……建造尖端工厂和数公里新道路是一场胜利……科学发现和新技术——这些也是胜利。” 。

这样的言论暗示了普京对待战争方式的核心矛盾。他希望调动更多的人力和资金进行战斗，同时通过尽可能少地干扰俄罗斯人的生活来获得他们的默许。随着越来越多的权力和资源在俄罗斯内部重新分配，这一矛盾将变得更加突出。六月份，他的政权迎来了迄今为止最不稳定的时刻，当时军队和瓦格纳（普京的密友叶夫根尼·普里戈任领导的雇佣军组织）之间的争吵升级为彻底的叛变。尽管普里戈任先生很快做出了让步，并随后在一次方便的飞机失事中丧生，但这提醒人们，平衡俄罗斯精英内部的竞争利益并不容易。随着经济混乱加剧和资源变得更加稀缺，这些冲突只会加剧。 ■

更正（2023年12月13日）：本文早期版本称俄罗斯今年第三季度通胀同比达到12%。事实上，这是年化的季度环比率。对不起。

; Thu, 30 Nov 2023 15:24:54 GMT /内容/881jjv62jbv3h7g68iq405956sk1471h https://www.economist.com/briefing/2023/11/30/how-putin-is-reshaping-Russia-to-keep-his-war-machine-running乌克兰俄罗斯 The messier the world gets, the more the UAE seems to thrive

从11 月30 日起，来自世界各地的 70,000 名人士将齐聚迪拜参加联合国年度气候峰会。众所周知，警察大会是一场为期 12 天的狂欢，吸引了外交官、商人和活动人士。如果他们有时间逃离世博城的拥挤，前往点缀在海岸上的耀眼摩天大楼，他们会发现一座城市和一个国家正处于惊人的繁荣之中。

一大群持有黄金签证的俄罗斯亿万富翁、印度商人和西方金融家是一大亮点。另一个是房地产热潮。九月，买家在凌晨排队抢购迪拜最新的豪华土地开垦项目杰贝阿里棕榈岛的别墅，起价为 500 万美元。该物业尚未建成。

去年能源价格飙升为全球最大石油生产国之一的阿拉伯联合酋长国带来了超过 1000 亿美元的收入。这相当于每个阿联酋公民大约 10 万美元。但石油并不是该国繁荣的唯一原因。在战争和经济分裂的时期，阿联酋似乎是风暴中的一个港口。跨国公司设立工厂和办事处的速度是阿联酋独立五十年来从未见过的。石油和天然气目前仅占国内生产总值的三分之一，而且经济中的石油部分的增长速度比其他部分慢。与2022年同期相比，上半年经济整体增长3.7%，剔除石油及相关行业增长5.9%（见图1）。

阿联酋在世界上的地位似乎也在迅速提高。举办COP 28 就是一个迹象。这个国家只有 1000 万人口，其中只有 100 万是公民。但通过其对全球业务的拥抱和包括清洁能源和物流在内的外国投资，它正在将自己与世界其他国家联系起来。它的经济开放性和非政治性的商业态度赋予它广泛的吸引力：它是美国人、中国人、伊朗人、以色列人和俄罗斯人共同接触的少数几个地方之一。

然而，阿联酋并非没有挑战。随着石油对经济的重要性降低，社会契约正在发生变化。政府并不是简单地赚取石油美元并以轻松的工作和补贴商品的形式将其分配给公民；而是将其分配给公民。它已开始征税并鼓励当地人在私营部门寻找要求更高的工作。由于阿联酋是绝对君主制国家（或者更确切地说，七个国家联合组成一个由阿布扎比最富有的人主导的联邦），因此民众的不满情绪几乎没有发泄的渠道。缺乏对统治者权威的制衡可能会导致任意且考虑不周的决策，尤其是在外交关系方面。

坎帆船精神

该国对经济转型并不陌生。潜水采珠业曾是海湾沿岸沉睡的贸易前哨的支柱，但在 20 世纪初期，日本研究人员找到了如何养殖珍珠后，采珠业就崩溃了。石油于 20 世纪 50 年代被发现；到 1971 年，阿联酋从英国统治下获得独立，它正逐步成为一个石油国家。它的石油储量比俄罗斯还多，是世界第七大生产国，每天生产超过 300 万桶。相对于其人口而言，只有圭亚那和科威特拥有更多的石油。

尽管有如此丰富的资源，阿联酋的统治者还是海湾地区最先尝试实现经济多元化的国家之一。迪拜本身几乎没有石油，因此率先创建了监管宽松、低税收的经济区，旨在吸引跨国公司。尽管在 2009 年发生严重的房地产崩盘后需要阿布扎比的救助，但其将自身转变为贸易转口港、交通枢纽和金融中心的基本经济模式仍然是成功的。与此同时，阿联酋将其石油财富投资于具有战略意义的行业和世界上具有战略意义的地区。其目的是使自己成为全球贸易、金融和地缘政治的一支力量。当地人傲慢地指出，邻国沙特阿拉伯王储穆罕默德·本·萨勒曼正在效仿这种做法。

首先从阿联酋航空作为转口港的角色开始。事实上，它距离非洲、欧洲和亚洲大部分地区都只有便捷的飞行和航运距离，这使其成为天然的枢纽。迪拜环球港务集团(DP World) 是迪拜政府旗下的一家公司，运营着全球最大的集装箱港口之一杰贝阿里 (Jebel Ali)。迪拜机场是世界上最繁忙的国际旅行机场。物流业占国内生产总值的比重已接近8%。

但商业环境与地理位置同样重要。在美国智库传统基金会编制的经济自由度指数中，阿联酋在 176 个国家中排名第 24 位，比美国高出一筹。外国人对设立办事处、租用公寓和批准签证的便利性表示赞赏。 “每个人都从商业角度思考，没有人从政治角度思考，”一位在迪拜拥有大型办公室的以色列企业家指出。以色列和哈马斯之间的战争开始几周后，他在访问该国时发现阿联酋一如既往地热情好客。地方政府运营“客户幸福中心”。这个名字令人难堪，而且本地服务可能很昂贵，但很有效。

近年来，企业在迪拜开办的速度非常快：与 2022 年相比，今年上半年加入该市商会的新企业数量增加了 40% 以上。其中五分之一是印度企业;来自中国和中东其他地区的企业数量也迅速增长。与此同时，阿布扎比在吸引金融公司方面取得了一些成功。

涌入反映了阿联酋可以为不同国家的公司发挥不同的作用。对于中国人来说，它已成为离岸贸易中心。一个例子是迪拜的龙城，这是一家批发和零售综合体，自称是中国境外最大的中国商品贸易中心。去年迪拜环球港务集团帮助建立了义乌市场，希望能超越义乌市场。对于印度公司来说，阿联酋提供了香港和新加坡为中国和东南亚所做的一切：一个更容易开展国际业务的地方，拥有更高效的法院、更好的基础设施以及获得资本和人才的机会。它也正在成为某种意义上的第二个家。印度首富穆克什·安巴尼 (Mukesh Ambani) 曾两次打破迪拜最昂贵住宅物业的记录，最近一次是价值 1.63 亿美元的海滩别墅。

对西方制裁的漠视使阿联酋成为来自被回避地区的企业的避风港。伊朗石油经常在富查伊拉酋长国附近的海上进行交换，与其他原油混合并出售。在日内瓦的贸易商开始避开俄罗斯原油后，迪拜成为融资和贸易货运的地方。无法再在美国或欧洲居住的俄罗斯商人已搬迁到迪拜的海滨别墅。与此同时，香港在大流行期间看似永无休止的封锁，导致一些专业人士逃往迪拜，而迪拜的新冠限制只持续了三个月。去年，以净值计算，移居阿联酋的百万富翁比世界其他任何地方都多。

近年来，对外国企业的欢迎变得更加热烈，这很可能是为了确保阿联酋保持相对于沙特阿拉伯的优势，沙特阿拉伯现在也在追逐外国公司。外来者曾经需要与阿联酋人合作在该国开店，这为当地人提供了丰厚的租金并减缓了商业形成。 “代理”规则已经放宽。周末已从周五和周六改为周六和周日，以与世界其他大部分地区保持一致（沙迦酋长国热衷于确保周五仍然是假期，因此每周工作四天）。个人自由也有所增加：例如，未婚夫妇现在可以住在一起。

但一个小国只能吸引这么多的业务，这就是阿联酋也在海外投资的原因。其各种主权财富基金在各类业务中拥有超过 1.5 万亿美元的资产（见图 2）。穆巴达拉的不同持股就是其中之一，其中包括美国金融科技公司 Chime、中国电动汽车制造商小鹏汽车以及安巴尼先生的电信网络 Jio 等公司的股份。

许多投资都集中在物流领域。迪拜环球港务集团(DP World) 经营着从伦敦到悉尼的各个港口。总而言之，全球至少十分之一的集装箱运输都经过该公司之手。

发展中国家也受到关注。阿联酋是资本匮乏的非洲最大的投资者之一，尽管主要是在北非。迪拜环球港务集团老板苏丹·艾哈迈德·本·苏拉耶姆在 2020 年表示：“我们正在非洲国家复制迪拜的成功。”2022 年，包括阿布扎比港口公司在内的阿联酋财团签署了一项协议，将投资 60 亿美元建设苏丹的港口和农业项目。迪拜环球港务集团也在陆地上开展业务：它在卢旺达投资了一个公路运输中心，根据咨询公司莱坊国际的一份报告，该中心将国内运输时间从几周缩短到几天。在印度，它投资了铁路线；在南部非洲的一家物流公司。

另一个利基市场是清洁能源。 2006 年，阿联酋下了一个有先见之明的赌注，成立了一家名为 Masdar 的公司，以实现能源供应多元化，并通过投资可再生能源来增强其能源专业知识（该公司最初由 Sultan al-Jaber 运营，他现在是阿布扎比国家石油公司的负责人）并担任COP 28 主席）。马斯达尔现在是世界上最大的风电场和太阳能开发商之一。

阿联酋官员希望在另一个新兴行业：人工智能中取得类似的成就。阿布扎比迅速尝试抓住该技术的潜力，建立了一个研究所，提供大量资金并招募了有才华的西方和中国研究人员。结果是 Falcon，一种开源大型语言模型，一些技术专家认为它比 Meta 的产品 Llama 2 更好。政府现在希望使用它作为特定领域（例如医疗保健）专有模型层的基础。它希望能够出售。现在说“猎鹰”是否会起飞还为时过早，但与大多数喋喋不休地谈论其人工智能战略的政府不同，阿联酋似乎确实拥有一个。

阿联酋还试图通过一系列双边经济和投资协议来促进其商业利益。它是《亚伯拉罕协议》的首批签署国之一，根据该协议，一些阿拉伯国家与以色列建立了关系。随后今年早些时候与以色列达成了贸易协议。尽管西方航空公司在 10 月 7 日哈马斯袭击后暂停了飞往特拉维夫的航班，但两家阿联酋航空公司 Flydubai 和阿提哈德航空仍维持正常航班。

印度去年与阿联酋签署了十年来的首份自由贸易协定。此后，双边贸易额名义增长了 16%。与印度尼西亚也达成了类似的协议；与泰国和马来西亚的谈判正在进行中。谈判的进展速度比海湾合作委员会（由所有石油资源丰富的海湾国家组成的组织）的同等努力要快得多，这使得阿联酋抢在了其邻国的前面。

然而，有时似乎是外交需要决定商业决策，而不是相反。阿联酋渴望在其地区建立影响力。本月早些时候，中国与约旦签署了一项协议，共同投资 20 亿美元用于基础设施和开发项目。它向土耳其总统雷杰普·塔伊普·埃尔多安做出了贸易和投资的承诺。它还大力支持陷入困境的埃塞俄比亚总理阿比·艾哈迈德，包括启动涉及迪拜环球港务集团和马斯达尔的大型项目。

事实上，在外交政策中，阿联酋总统和阿布扎比统治者穆罕默德·本·扎耶德的绝对且有时难以预测的权力最为明显。谢赫穆罕默德敌视伊斯兰教的政治表达，并热衷于重塑该地区以增加阿联酋的影响力。为此，他介入了利比亚、苏丹和也门的内战。

然而，在这三个地方，战争仍在继续，但没有结果。更重要的是，在这三个地方，阿联酋都发现自己与美国或沙特阿拉伯等亲密盟友存在分歧。更糟糕的是，尽管阿联酋在每个国家都支持似乎不太愿意将清真寺和国家合并的一方，但其盟友在其他方面却令人讨厌。例如，在苏丹，阿联酋支持的民兵被指控在达尔富尔地区对非洲黑人进行种族灭绝行动。

阿联酋声名狼藉的盟友经常促进其商业利益，这无济于事。在苏丹，他们通过控制金矿来筹集资金，金矿的产出主要在迪拜出售。阿联酋自然也渴望保护阿布扎比在苏丹的大笔投资。然而，这充其量是短视的：很难想象阿联酋从此类外交政策冒险中获得的任何商业利益会超过对其声誉的潜在损害。

酋长国有时会因其统治者的错误决定而感到失望，这不仅仅是在外交政策方面。它做出了有先见之明的经济押注，但也做出了鲁莽的押注。从迪拜驱车前往阿布扎比，您会经过一片荒凉的土地，这片土地原本是用来建造主题公园的，但实际上却从未建成。 2018 年，联邦政府承诺到 2021 年将有一半的交易在区块链上进行；迪拜官员曾承诺“到2020年将完全由区块链驱动”。同样的道理，营商环境也并不完美。该政权可能是专断和严厉的，例如，外国商人有时会在没有任何解释的情况下被拘留。

到目前为止，此类失误还没有严重到足以在阿联酋公民或投资者中造成不安，从而损害其作为政治和经济稳定避风港的声誉。但随着其经济变得更加多元化，阿联酋的外交纠葛变得更加复杂，管理所有相互竞争的利益成为一项更加微妙的任务。与此同时，这名警察提醒人们，阿联酋看似深不可测的财富实际上可能是一种浪费的资产。

石油资金使阿联酋能够向世界开放其经济，而不会让阿联酋人遭受任何痛苦。阿布扎比是世界上成本最低的生产国之一，因此即使在消费下降的世界中，阿布扎比仍将继续从事石油业务。但它正在为财富可能减少的时刻做准备。在某种程度上，这意味着让阿联酋对外国劳动力和企业更具吸引力。但这也意味着寻找替代收入来源并削减成本。政府开征增值税和企业所得税。燃油补贴已于 2015 年逐步取消。没有人大声疾呼，但个人所得税似乎也是不可避免的。

更多的阿联酋人需要从公共部门转向私营部门，但许多人不合格，这意味着他们不太可能因此变得更富有。小学生在标准化考试中远远落后于富裕国家的小学生，而且辍学率很高。到目前为止，社会契约的取消已经引起了抱怨，但并没有引起骚乱。要保持这种状态，需要更加协调一致地培训劳动力，并采取微妙的措施。

阿联酋很快就发现了碎片化世界中的机遇。然而新时代也带来了危险。如果全球摆脱化石燃料的转变成为现实，那将是一个冲击。阿联酋咄咄逼人的外交政策将继续对其联盟造成压力。特别是，它与沙特阿拉伯的关系可能会变得更加复杂和更具竞争力。过去 50 年的经验表明，做空阿联酋是愚蠢的，但最艰难的考验仍在前方。 ■

; Thu, 23 Nov 2023 10:52:27 GMT /内容/f3nl20jrtr1s646avd0bceevg8igder5 https://www.economist.com/briefing/2023/11/23/the-messier-the-world-gets-the-more-the-uae-seems-to-thrive Now AI can write, sing and act, is it still possible to be a star?

在过去的六个月里，每个工作日都有一群群美丽的人聚集在好莱坞电影制片厂外，高呼口号，在阳光下游行。美国的编剧和演员引人注目，部分原因是担心人工智能（ AI ）很快就会开始编写剧本甚至扮演角色。 “你去找工作，他们就会扫描你，”一位背景女演员说道，她担心自己的脸会在人群场景中一遍又一遍地出现。另一位人士表示，这项技术“令人作呕”，他认为它的使用“侵犯了你自己和你的职业生涯”。 11 月 8 日，协议参与者达成了结束罢工的协议，其中包括针对人为竞争对手的保护措施。

5000 英里之外，经常可以看到另一群充满活力的人群在谈论人工智能，通常是在天气阴沉但精神振奋的情况下。在伦敦东部一个专门建造的体育场外，各个年龄段的人们（其中一些穿着奇装异服）每周七次聚集在一起观看ABBA Voyage，在这场表演中，一个七十多岁的流行乐队通过虚拟化身演奏了长达 90 分钟的充满活力的表演。在人工智能的帮助下生成。该节目于 2022 年推出，第一年就吸引了 100 万人次观看，大多数夜晚仍然几乎售空，据报道每周收入为 20 万美元，而ABBA的四位成员也都在奋力拼搏。

人工智能是否会像好莱坞抗议的演员和作家所担心的那样，让人才变得匮乏，还是像ABBA所发现的那样，进一步丰富人才？明星们紧张的原因很容易理解。多年来，技术已经自动化取代了娱乐业的许多日常工作，但商业核心的创造性工作却受到了保护。不再。生成式人工智能正在吸纳受版权保护的作品，并制作出各种各样的重新混合的文学、音乐和视频，在质量上日益与人类竞争，并且在数量上已经远远超过了人类。在人工智能生成内容无限的世界里，成为明星还有可能吗？

人才们正在动员工会、律师和政客来保护自己。好莱坞的编剧们在九月结束了为期五个月的罢工，并赢得了制片厂的承诺，在电影和电视节目中雇用最低数量的人类编剧。工作室保留使用人工智能生成或润色剧本的权利，但人工智能不会被视为作者，因此人类作家的版税不会被稀释。就作家而言，他们保留在自己的作品中使用人工智能的权利。 （尽管他们不喜欢它，但许多人认为人工智能是“他们曾经拥有过的最好的写作伙伴”，一位好莱坞经纪人承认。）

截至《经济学人》付印时，演员们与制片厂和流媒体服务的交易细节尚未公布，但他们的工会美国演员工会表示，其中包括“前所未有的同意和赔偿条款，将保护成员免受威胁”的人工智能”。这可能意味着，如果演员的肖像或声音要通过数字方式复活，他们至少会收到通知并获得报酬。

我起诉，我起诉，我起诉，我起诉，我起诉

球星的第二道防线是合法的。包括约翰·格里沙姆（John Grisham，《公司》和其他几十部惊悚小说的作者）和乔治·RR·马丁（George RR Martin，《权力的游戏》的作者）在内的一群作者对 Open AI （Chat GPT背后的微软支持公司）提起集体诉讼，辩称它未经许可或付款就摄取了他们的作品。包括全球最大唱片公司环球音乐集团在内的另一方投诉称，亚马逊和谷歌支持的人工智能公司 Anthropic 对歌词做了类似的事情。

科技公司认为，在受版权保护的作品上“训练”人工智能模型相当于合理使用。用埃默里大学马修·萨格的话说，人工智能并不是“像修道院里的抄写员”那样抄书，而是像学生一样从中学习。训练数据，无论是小说还是歌曲，通常在模型的输出中发挥的作用很小，几乎无法追踪。但不总是。 “如果你说，‘按照丹·布朗（《达芬奇密码》）的风格写作，那当然会借鉴丹·布朗的书，”代表作家的作家协会主席玛丽·拉森伯格表示。

随着法院采取行动，政府也介入其中。 10 月 30 日，美国总统乔·拜登发布行政命令，制定人工智能发展的基本规则。美国版权局正在对人工智能进行调查，调查将于本月晚些时候结束评论。

一位音乐行业内部人士警告说，政府可能会竞相创造最“宽松”的监管环境，以吸引人工智能公司。其他人则以过去的技术驱动颠覆浪潮为例，认为有妥协的空间。当音乐流媒体出现时，“我们变得非常防御，而且只是防御，”另一位唱片公司高级管理人员承认。唱片公司花了十年时间才意识到这项技术对商业有利，并与流媒体平台达成了协议。他预测，与人工智能公司的谈判将花费不到一半的时间。 “这是需要共存的。”

当法律确定后，技术上谁会赢谁会输？从表面上看，最大牌的明星似乎最脆弱。人工智能帮助普通人缩小与最有天赋的人的差距。不那么光鲜亮丽的行业已经见证了这一点。 4 月份，斯坦福大学的 Erik Brynjolfsson 等人发表的一份工作论文发现，新手客户支持代理在使用聊天机器人后，工作效率提高了 35%，而经验丰富的代理却几乎没有受益。

演艺界也发生了类似的事情。甚至在人工智能出现之前，自动调音等工具就可以帮助普通人听起来更像他们的偶像。下一代技术有望使这些功能更加强大。 TikTok 的母公司字节跳动正在试用一款名为 Ripple 的应用程序，该应用程序可以将用户在手机中唱的任何旋律转化为优美的歌曲。 Boomy 是一家美国初创公司，让业余作曲家只需点击几下即可生成原创音乐，并将其上传到 Spotify 等流媒体平台上以赚取版税。

借助 Vanity AI等工具的数字化改造，古板的演员可以与华丽的演员竞争，这些工具被用于《怪奇物语》和《行尸走肉》等制作中，根据需要让演员看起来更漂亮或更可怕。迟钝的作家可以从 Sudowrite 等应用程序中获得灵感，它会提出新的想法和编辑。它简洁地将自己定位为“你一直想要的不带评判性、随时可以再读一份草稿、即使在凌晨 3 点也不会耗尽想法的人工智能写作伙伴”。

AI制作的好作品并不多，更不用说耀眼到足以与天赋树顶端的明星竞争了。但它已经开始通过巨大的规模产生影响。 Boomy 声称已经生成了近 1800 万首歌曲（相比之下，Spotify 的整个目录略多于 1 亿首）。 Spotify 现在每天都会添加超过 100,000 首新曲目，其中许多是人工智能制作的。环球音乐总裁卢西恩·格兰奇爵士警告说，随着流媒体平台充斥着业余曲目，真正的音乐可能会淹没在“噪音的海洋”中。专业艺术家的聆听份额确实在下降。 2017 年，与唱片公司签约的艺术家占 Spotify 流媒体播放量的 87%。去年他们的份额仅为 75%。

人工智能很难做出真正的热门音乐，但它擅长制作人们在工作或睡觉时播放的背景音乐。这些曲目的播放时间很长，因此在流媒体使用的付费模式下可以获得丰厚的回报。一些业内人士怀疑，流媒体平台欢迎业余艺术家的崛起，而业余艺术家的议价能力不如大唱片公司。另一位唱片公司高管表示，流媒体可能会促使听众关注这些内容的想法“绝对令人担忧”。他认为唯一阻止他们的是惹恼听众的风险。主播们反驳说，宣传不良音乐根本不符合他们的利益。今年早些时候，Spotify 清除了许多人工智能制作的歌曲，据说正在重新调整其规则，以降低低质量壁纸音乐的利润； Deezer 和 Tidal 这两个规模较小的竞争对手也采取了类似的措施。

出版界也有类似的抱怨。通过人工智能制作整本书是如此快速和容易，以至于今年 9 月，亚马逊禁止作者每天在其 Kindle 平台上自行出版超过三本电子书，并要求出版商明确标记机器人作家的书籍。大多数人工智能文本都充满了陈词滥调和胡言乱语（一位代理人讽刺道，这使得它们在管理领域具有竞争力）。但有些人通过欺骗手段夺走了人类作家的销量：例如，作家协会发现人工智能制作的传记在真实的回忆录出版之前就出现了。 “点击农场”也被用来操纵亚马逊的排名。 The guild says that, at one point this summer, 40 of the top 100 young-adult romance books on Kindle were AI -written.

The winner makes it all

Yet far from sinking in this sea of AI -made entertainment, the biggest stars of all seem to be more buoyant than ever. As record labels worry about robot composers, Taylor Swift is halfway through what will probably be the highest-earning concert tour in history, with projected sales of $1.4bn or more (no previous tour has breached $1bn). An accompanying film has made an additional $230m at the box office. Colleen Hoover, a writer of romantic young-adult fiction, crushed the robot writers last year to bag eight places on the top-25 bestseller list in America, selling 14m copies, according to Publishers Weekly , a trade title.

One of the paradoxes of the internet age is that, amid an explosion in online content on platforms from YouTube to TikTok, fans have flocked as never before to the biggest acts. It has been a good time to be an amateur creator, but an even better time to be a superstar. Data from Spotify show that between 2017 and 2022, as the platform was flooded with tens of millions of amateur tracks, the number of artists making at least $1,000 a year in royalties increased by 155%. At the same time, the number making $5m or more increased by 165%, and the handful of headliners making $10m or more increased by 425% (see chart 1 on previous page). Those who have done least well are middling-to-big artists, who face more competition from entertainment's long tail but have been unable to break into the elite group at the top.

Similar patterns can be seen across the entertainment world. Better and cheaper technology has democratised filmmaking. The number of movies released each year in America more than doubled during the first two decades of the 21st century, but the audience-share of the biggest blockbusters has grown, not shrunk. In 2019 (the last year before the pandemic) America's five biggest films took a quarter of the domestic box office, nearly double the share they took in the less crowded market of 2000 (see chart 2). Meanwhile, the ten bestselling authors have accounted for a steady 2-3% of book sales in Britain over the past decade, according to Nielsen, a data company, even though 2m more books are self-published each year.

Lay all your likes on me

“Hits will persist in an infinite-content world,” argues Doug Shapiro, a former media executive. The bewildering variety makes it hard for consumers to pick, so they rely more on recommendations, whether from friends or algorithms. Rather than browse, people seek out what they have already heard of, says Ms Rasenberger of the Authors Guild. “Known writers are selling. And everyone else is having a much harder time.”

AI also helps superstars shine brighter by creating opportunities for their admirers to become superfans. Followers of a music act used to express themselves chiefly through “records, T -shirts and mix-tapes”, says an industry executive. Now the internet offers “mix-tapes on steroids”. Fans can duet with their idols or dance to their music on social media. Games like “Fortnite” have provided a venue for interactive experiences: Ariana Grande held a concert-game hybrid on the platform in 2021, attracting 27m participants.

AI -powered technology promises to allow the biggest stars to be in even more places, gratifying even more fans. The producers of ABBA Voyage are in talks to bring the show to cities in North America, South-East Asia and Australasia, according to Per Sundin, head of Pophouse, a Swedish entertainment company that is the biggest investor in the enterprise. Other artists have been in touch, looking to “cement and elevate their legacies” with similar shows, he says. “We now have a proven template.”

Stars do not need to build their own arena like ABBA to use ai to be in more places at once. Spotify is working with Open AI to translate podcasts into different languages, allowing broadcasters to be heard in more markets, in their own voice. Other firms such as HeyGen provide dubbing services for video, using AI to change the movement of the actor's lips to match what they are saying. HeyGen recently created a viral video of Ms Swift appearing to speak fluent Chinese. Such platforms can adapt content in other ways, too, for instance by toning down strong language for a broader audience. Technology like this will allow stars to reach more viewers—and presents a problem to the lowlier actors who specialise in dubbing.

Stars are also using ai to travel in time. John Lennon re-entered the charts on November 2nd with “Now and Then”, old recordings of his voice having been salvaged using AI . (“I hope someone does this to all my crap demos after I'm dead—make them into hit songs,” said his late fellow Beatle, George Harrison, of an earlier attempt to resurrect Lennon's work.) James Earl Jones, who is 92 and first voiced Darth Vader almost 50 years ago, has sold Disney the right to replicate his gravelly tones artificially. A virtual Darth appeared in Disney's “Obi-Wan Kenobi” last year.

Some artists are experimenting with licensing their voice or image more widely. In April Grimes, a Canadian singer, invited amateur composers to clone her voice for use in their songs, provided they share any royalties with her. In September Meta launched 28 chatbot characters, played by celebrities. Snoop Dogg, Paris Hilton and Charlie D'Amelio are among the B -listers to be botified, with one reportedly being paid $5m over two years. Mark Zuckerberg, Meta's boss, invites stars to “build an AI version of yourself…to help people fulfil this desire to interact with you and your desire to build a community.”

A -listers remain wary: “Their voice is their career,” says a record executive. But even if they do not license their voice or likeness, others may still borrow them. A company called Socialdraft sells $5 “prompts” to make chatbots take on the personality of celebrities ranging from Tom Cruise to Josef Stalin, who do not appear to have given their permission. It is named in a legal complaint by a group of authors including Mr Grisham, whom it also impersonates. (Socialdraft denies wrongdoing. Antonio Evans, its chief executive, says, “The interplay between AI , copyright and individual rights is a thrilling narrative we are all part of.”)

Some unauthorised clones have become hits. In April an anonymous amateur composer released a song called “Heart On My Sleeve”, using the AI -replicated voices of two rappers, Drake and The Weeknd. The song was streamed 20m times before Universal, which represents the two artists, demanded it be taken down.

The track caused alarm, but it also demonstrated how cloning can work in artists' favour. Analysis by Will Page, author of “Pivot” and a former chief economist at Spotify, suggests that being cloned can help stars sell genuine music. He calculates that after David Guetta, a French DJ , posted a clip of an AI -generated rap in the style of Eminem in February, streams of real Eminem tracks rose by about a fifth.

Yet antipathy to AI remains fierce. A group of actors, writers and directors has set up an outfit called Credo23 to certify films and TV shows made without AI (it has yet to take off). Many singers, burned by digital piracy in the past, are also hostile. Sir Cliff Richard, an 83-year-old crooner, recently declared that his singing “didn't use artificial insemination”.

Others fear that AI will simply make entertainment derivative and boring. Three-quarters of Americans tell YouGov, a pollster, that they worry AI will sap human creativity. The process of ingesting everything and then spitting out an average may lead to a stylistic and conceptual regression to the mean, says a literary agent, who sees similarities with the algorithms on social media that help propagate the most pedestrian views. Sir Lucian, at Universal, has said that AI “will always lack the essential spark that drives the most talented artists to do their best work, which is intention”.

Everything depends on whether audiences embrace artificial performances. “Is the next generation of moviegoers going to want to see a different actor in James Bond, as an example? Or are they going to want to see Sean Connery come back?” asks a Hollywood agent.对于最大的明星， AI生成的表演可能是最成功的，他们的不批判性超级球员无法获得足够的能力。 As Liam Gallagher, a former Oasis frontman and John Lennon devotee, replied when asked on social media what he thought of the remastered “Now and Then”: “The Beatles could shit in my hand bag I'd still hide my polo mints in there ”。 ■

; Thu, 09 Nov 2023 09:56:28 GMT /content/eoqrkuic0pt1gnnakeumo1cgj5dodaid https://www.economist.com/briefing/2023/11/09/now-ai-can-write-sing-and-act-is-it-still-possible-to-be-a-star人工智能 Markets think interest rates could stay high for a decade or more

N OT LONG ago, as interest rates in the rich world hovered near zero, economists debated whether their downward march was the product of a decades-, centuries- or millennia-long trend.现在最紧迫的问题是它们将保持高位多久。 10月18日，包含长期利率预期、2021年时还低于1%的十年期国债收益率触及4.9%，为2007年以来的最高水平。当天，30年期国债收益率突破5% 。美国银行分析师上个月宣布利率“正脱离 5000 年来的低点”时，听起来可能有点喘不过气来。但这确实是经济学家、投资者和任何在偿还债务时处于不舒服地位的人的感受，因为几乎每个人都预计利率将永远处于低位。

The conviction that rates will remain “higher for longer” is spreading around the world. The euro zone saw negative interest rates in 2021; now Germany must pay nearly 3% to borrow for a decade. Britain's bond yields are nearly as high as America's. Even Japan, whose apparently permanently low rates were seen as a harbinger for the rest of the world, has faced upward pressure on its bond yields (see chart 1). Bets that its central bank will have to raise interest rates in 2024 for the first time since 2007 are mounting.

If markets are right, a new era is beginning and the consequences will be far reaching. Households and companies will have to pay much more to borrow. The financial system will have to adjust to a painful new reality. And governments will find they have to divert more tax revenue to pay the interest on their accumulated debt. The higher-for-longer scenario that many investors are now predicting is a potentially toxic mix.

Start with the real economy. One of the surprises of the past year is how resilient the world economy—and particularly America—has been in the face of higher rates. On October 26th it was revealed that America's GDP grew at an annualised pace of 4.9% in the third quarter. Consumer spending has been supported by the excess savings households built up thanks to the lockdowns and stimulus payments of the covid-19 pandemic. Many firms issued long-term debt when rates were low, and so continue to enjoy low financing costs today. Net interest payments by America's companies have actually fallen this year, because the interest they earn on the cash they keep to hand has risen faster than the cost of servicing their debts.

These protective buffers will last for a while yet. In September statisticians revised up the estimate of savings accumulated during the pandemic, which had previously looked like they were on the verge of exhaustion. It now appears that America's households are still sitting on about $1trn of excess cash, equal to nearly 5% of annual personal income in aggregate. It will also take time for higher rates to slow companies down. Goldman Sachs, a bank, estimates that just 16% of America's corporate debt will mature over the next few years. Refinancing it will lift the average interest rate on the total stock of debt from 4.2% this year to just 4.5% in 2025.

Not all companies are resilient to higher rates, however. Smaller American firms, whose debts typically fall due sooner than those of big ones, are under strain even though the economy is booming. There and in Europe, where growth is weaker, corporate bankruptcies are rising (see chart 2). In some economies firms are much more exposed to rising rates: at the end of 2021 the median maturity of Spanish and Italian businesses' debts was only 2.6 years and 2.1 years respectively. In Sweden, where corporate debt is an eye-watering 155% of GDP , the average effective interest rate on outstanding bank loans to companies rose from 1.5% to 3.9% in the year to March and will be higher still by now. In September the number of corporate bankruptcies was 14% higher than a year earlier.

Were rates to reach a permanently higher plateau, even long-dated debt would eventually start to cost companies dear. That would be painful because during the 2010s firms borrowed heavily: America's non-financial corporations issued a net $4.1trn in debt over that decade while retiring a net $3.2trn of equity through dividends and buy-backs. In advanced economies as a whole, corporate debt is around 93% of GDP , up from less than 80% in the mid-2000s, according to data from the IMF . If rates stay higher for longer, this borrowing binge may need to be unwound. A long period of deleveraging could therefore inhibit investment in the 2020s, just as low growth inhibited it in the 2010s.

Home is where the hurt is

Households, too, will eventually find that higher rates bite. In America and some European countries interest rates on mortgages can be fixed for decades, which protects borrowers from rate rises as long as they do not move house. But house prices are likely to fall, because they depend mostly on buyers who borrow afresh, and therefore face much higher costs. On October 18th Mortgage News Daily, a data provider, reported that the average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage in America carried an interest rate of 8% for the first time since 2000. As a result the monthly payment required to buy the median American home with a mortgage worth 90% of the property's value is now nearly 60% of average earnings, up from 33% in July 2021.

It strains credulity to think that housing markets can sustain such ratios. According to the Bank for International Settlements, real house prices in 12 advanced economies fell by 10% between the start of 2022 and the second quarter of 2023. Should rates follow the path implied by markets, real house prices should fall by another 14% by the end of 2025. In a scenario in which interest rates stabilise slightly above their current level, the peak-to-trough fall in real house prices would reach 35%. For comparison, the fall prompted by the global financial crisis was 13%.

Next, consider the implication of higher rates for the financial sector. Traders often joke that interest rates go up until something breaks. In the spring of 2023 something did: banks. They own lots of government bonds, which lose value as rates rise. The jump in the yield of ten-year Treasuries from 1.5% at the end of 2021 to around 3.5% a year later drove down the value of a broad index of Treasury bonds by about 10%. That inflicted over $600bn of losses on American banks, the most vulnerable of which—Silicon Valley Bank and First Republic—suffered runs and failed. The crisis was eventually forestalled by the Federal Reserve offering to lend to banks against the face value, rather than the market value, of their Treasuries, easing the pressure on their balance sheets.

But in a higher-for-longer world, the crisis could return. The last loans under the Fed's new lending scheme are to be made in March. Even if it is extended, banks may find themselves unable to afford to pay the interest on the Fed loans (which is similar to prevailing short-term rates and so has been rising steadily).

And it is not just Treasuries whose market value falls when rates rise. More or less any loan paying a fixed return over a medium-to-long duration will follow the same pattern. Erica Jiang, Gregor Matvos, Tomasz Piskorski and Amit Seru, a group of economists, undertook an analysis that valued all the assets of American banks at the market prices that prevailed in March and then tested to see what would happen if half or all of their uninsured depositors withdrew their savings. They found that, even under the less apocalyptic scenario, some 200 or so banks, with collective assets of $300bn, would potentially be insolvent. Another paper, by Mark Flannery and Sorin Sorescu, two more economists, concluded, “If all unbooked losses were fully reflected in bank balance sheets, roughly half of all banks, holding roughly half of all bank assets, would not meet their minimum regulatory capital要求。”

Since March the bond index has fallen by 5% more. Ms Jiang and her co-authors have repeated their analysis. They find that unrealised losses have climbed modestly, but are now concentrated at bigger banks. In March only some 30% of the $2.2trn of these losses were at banks labelled “systemically important” by regulators. Now there are $2.5trn of unrealised losses, with about two-thirds at such banks.

There are other sources of financial vulnerability, too. Commercial property loans make up around a tenth of bank assets, and the value of office buildings has collapsed owing to higher interest rates and lower occupancy. Some owners have simply handed the keys to lenders. What is more, much lending has migrated in recent years from banks to other sorts of financial institutions, such as pension funds and insurance firms. They have never gone through a cycle of rising rates as big lenders before. Although the dispersal of risk is in principle helpful, it also means a greater number of firms face potential losses.

Last, consider the vulnerability of governments. After the global financial crisis, rich countries' public debts surged to the highest level since 1946. Since the pandemic they have been larger, relative to GDP , than at any time since the Napoleonic wars (see chart 3).这些巨大的债务的可持续性不仅取决于利率，还取决于这些利率与经济增长相比。 In the low-rate era it became fashionable to note that if GDP expands faster than interest accrues, then a government's debt-to- GDP ratio can shrink even as it borrows afresh to pay its interest bill. It may even be able to borrow more still to fund extra spending while keeping its debt-to- GDP ratio stable.

In October the IMF projected that, between 2023 and 2028, the economic growth rate in advanced economies will continue to exceed the interest rate their governments pay on their debts, by 1.4 percentage points on average, despite recent rate rises. The reason is that governments, like companies, have locked in low rates to some degree by issuing long-term debt.

Yet debt-to- GDP ratios are mostly set to rise anyway, because many governments continue to run excessive deficits. America especially is borrowing with abandon: strip out accounting distortions and its deficit for the past year was 7.5% of GDP , according to the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, a think-tank. Deficits that high are typically seen only during wars or catastrophic recessions. The Economist calculated the fiscal adjustments that advanced economies would need to make to keep their debts stable, given the IMF ’s projections. In every big advanced economy bar Germany and Japan, belt-tightening is needed to stop the debt-to- GDP ratio from rising further. America would have to trim its primary budget deficit—ie, its deficit excluding interest on its debt—by an annual 2.4% of GDP . Such parsimony will be especially difficult given the extra spending that is needed to cope with ageing populations, the climate crisis and rising geopolitical tensions—the annual bill for all of which, the IMF estimates, will add up to about 7.5% of gdp in rich国家。

What is more, in a higher-for-longer world governments, like companies, must refinance eventually. Ten-year yields are now above plausible estimates of long-run growth in most rich economies. That means much more belt-tightening could be needed to keep debts from rising. It is hard to escape the conclusion that, on current growth forecasts, higher-for-longer would force governments into another round of painful budget-balancing like that suffered by Europe in the 2010s. If upheaval in the finance industry prompts expensive bail-outs, the fiscal outlook would become yet bleaker.

There is always cope

Can the world economy cope with corporate deleveraging, falling house prices, turmoil at banks and fiscal frugality? Surprisingly, the answer is, perhaps—if rates have risen for the right reason. Economists typically think that interest rates are determined in the long term by the balance between the world's desire to save and to invest. All else equal, more saving pulls down the so-called “natural” rate of interest; more investment pushes it up. The most popular explanation for the rock-bottom rates of the 2010s was that ageing populations were stashing away more money for retirement, while insipid long-term growth prospects had sapped companies of the desire to expand—a phenomenon sometimes called “secular stagnation”.

For rates to have shifted permanently, that outlook must have changed.它可能存在的一个可能原因是，人们可能会因人工智能（ AI ）的最新进展而对更快的经济增长的期望。 In the long term, growth and interest rates are intimately linked. When people's incomes rise over time, they have less need to save. Companies, expecting higher sales, become keener to invest. Central banks have to keep rates higher to stop economies from overheating.

It might seem farfetched to say that optimism about AI is pushing up bond yields. Yet it would explain why the prospect of higher-for-longer has not caused stockmarkets to fall much. In theory, higher bond yields should reduce the value of companies' future earnings, an effect that bites hardest for technology firms, since they tend to promise jam tomorrow. In fact, as optimism about AI has spread, the value of big tech firms such as Microsoft and Nvidia has soared. Their rising value has kept the cyclically adjusted price-earnings ratio of the S & P 500 at around pre-pandemic levels, even though bond yields—and hence the rate used to discount future profits—are now much higher. And America's strong growth in the third quarter was not driven by an unusual jobs boom; in fact, the labour market is cooling. If the growth number is accurate, productivity must have risen.

To the extent that productivity growth explains higher rates, the new era could be a happy one. Alongside the rise in debt-service costs, households will have higher real incomes, firms will have higher revenues, financial institutions will enjoy low default rates and governments will collect more tax. Healthy competition for capital might even bring benefits of its own. Some economists long suspected that the low-rate era of the 2010s made the economy less dynamic. “It was easy for relatively inefficient companies to stay afloat, so there wasn't much creative destruction,” says Kristin Forbes of MIT . In a higher-rate world underpinned by faster growth, there would be plenty of dynamism.

Alas, there is a more worrying explanation for higher rates: that government debt has grown so large that it has sopped up the world's surplus savings, leaving the private sector to compete for the scraps. In the short term, many traders blame the avalanche of debt issuance since the pandemic, as well as the unwinding of big bond purchases at central banks, for rising bond yields. Economists often pooh-pooh the significance of existing bonds changing hands, but they do think the size of the outstanding stock of debt matters. A rule of thumb proposed in 2019 by Larry Summers of Harvard University and Lukasz Rachel, then at the Bank of England, is that a ten-percentage-point increase in debt-to- GDP raises interest rates by 0.35 percentage points in the long run, while every percentage point increase in deficits raises rates by a similar amount. That would imply that spendthrift governments have contributed to today's high rates.

To the extent government debt is to blame for “higher-for-longer”, then the world economy will have to deal with higher rates without any accompanying fillip to growth.那会很痛苦。 “You can't really take the view that deficits will continue to push interest rates up and will also continue unchecked,” says Maurice Obstfeld of the Peterson Institute for International Economics. “Something's got to give, whether it's a more restrictive fiscal policy or some sort of debt crisis.”

Other than a fiscal crisis, how could the tension be resolved? One possibility is that persistently high inflation could erode the real value of government debts, as it has in the past after moments of economic crisis. In that case, though nominal interest rates might be higher-for-longer, the real interest rate would not have risen as much. Companies and governments would survive high rates because their incomes would be strong in cash terms. Relative to the high real yields they expect today, bondholders would be squeezed.

Another possibility is that high rates push the world economy into a recession, which in turn causes central banks to cut them. In line with this thesis, on October 23rd Bill Ackman of Pershing Square Capital announced that his fund was no longer betting that rates would keep rising, pushing down the value of Treasuries. “There is too much risk in the world to remain short bonds at current long-term rates,” he wrote. “The economy is slowing faster than recent data suggests.” If he is right, higher may not be for that much longer. ■

I T ALL BEGAN so fast. An unprecedented barrage of rockets served as cover for a murderous rampage, which led to a frantic manhunt and ferocious air strikes. Reservists rushed to don uniforms and report for duty. Generals promised a massive ground offensive. What began as a sleepy autumn weekend ended with Israel making ready to invade Gaza.

Read all our coverage of the war between Israel and Hamas

Nearly three weeks after the October 7th massacre in Israel, however, that offensive has yet to begin. Israel's bombardment of Gaza continues, killing thousands and destroying around 9% of buildings in the territory . A near-total siege has left civilians short of food and water and hospitals unable to function.

Apart from a few small raids, though, the ground troops have yet to move. Some of the 360,000 reservists called up in Israel's largest-ever mobilisation have been sent home. Tens of thousands more are still in southern Israel, awaiting orders that have been delayed and delayed again.

Officers grumble that they cannot maintain their readiness forever. One frustrated commander took his troops to a building site to run up and down half-finished high-rises—ostensibly an urban-warfare drill. In reality, he says, it was a way to let off steam. “Hurry up and wait” is a perennial maxim of military life; but an especially stark one in Israel today.

There are many reasons to delay: continuing talks to free the array of hostages held by Hamas, the militant Islamist group that runs Gaza; American pressure, motivated by fears of a regional war; the dire conditions inside Gaza; and the chronic dithering of Binyamin Netanyahu, Israel's long-serving prime minister. On October 25th he confirmed that a ground offensive is still planned. But it will be smaller and slower than anyone would have expected in the days after the massacre, in which Hamas militants murdered more than 1,400 people, most of them civilians.

According to the latest count from Israeli officials, the tally of at least 220 people seized during the attack includes scores of children and old people, and citizens of at least a dozen foreign countries. The hostages have become a source of pressure on Mr Netanyahu's government. The captives' families have waged an effective public-relations campaign, and foreign leaders have pushed him to try to free their citizens.

Vigils have been held across Israel. The hostages' relatives often give television and radio interviews. The issue is deeply political. Many of those from the kibbutzim that were attacked are the secular, left-leaning sorts of Israelis most likely to have joined protests against Mr Netanyahu's government throughout the year. They feel his government forsook them on October 7th and is still failing them. Pressure from the families has already forced the government to change its plans. Originally inclined to rush into Gaza without regard for the hostages' safety, it has since declared that their rescue is a “top priority”.

Qatar, host to some leaders of Hamas, is also feeling the heat. Its ties with the group have come under scrutiny since the massacre; it is desperate to show its Western partners, particularly America, that it can serve as an interlocutor.

On October 25th Tzachi Hanegbi, the head of Israel's national-security council, posted an uncharacteristic message on X (formerly Twitter): “I'm pleased to say that Qatar is becoming an essential party and stakeholder in the facilitation of humanitarian solutions,”他写了。 Israeli officials had been scathing about Qatar in recent weeks. That Mr Hanegbi praised it (in English, rather than Hebrew) suggests progress towards a deal to release at least some of Hamas's captives.

Hamas has already let a handful go. On October 20th it freed a mother and daughter who hold dual American and Israeli citizenship. Three days later it freed two elderly Israeli women who were abducted from Nir Oz, a kibbutz on the Gaza border.它一无所获，这表明美国对卡塔尔的压力正在产生影响。

One of the women, Yocheved Lifshitz, 85, spoke of her ordeal at a press conference the next day. Her captors, she said, beat her on the journey to Gaza. Once inside the territory she was led into a “spiderweb” of tunnels; after walking for hours, she wound up in a room where around two dozen other hostages were being held.

Ms Lifshitz said they were treated decently: medics tended to the wounded, and captives ate the same simple meals of bread, cheese and vegetables as their captors. When she was turned over to the Red Cross on Gaza's border with Egypt, she shook hands with one of her captors. She said that was because the hostages were treated with “sensitivity”. But her husband is still in captivity: she had good reason not to antagonise Hamas.

That the group behaved humanely to a grandmother, moreover, does not mitigate the outrage of having kidnapped a grandmother in the first place, tossing her across a motorbike and beating her with sticks. Nor does it excuse the horrors of what Hamas did in Israeli towns.

On October 23rd the Israeli army screened 43 minutes of raw footage from the massacre for foreign journalists.其中一些是从攻击者的身体摄像机中获取的，其余的来自监视摄像机和手机。在放映时，在陆军基地上的一个不起眼的礼堂中不允许录制：这是一部虐待狂的鼻烟电影，而不是公众的眼睛。

In one harrowing clip a father rushes his two young sons, all of them clad in their underclothes, to a hiding place. A terrorist throws in a hand grenade after them. The father is killed. The bloodied boys—one appears to have lost an eye—are led back into their house at gunpoint, where their father's killer asks them for water, calmly raids the fridge and starts drinking a cola. (An army spokesman was unable to say if the boys survived.)

The atrocities go on. A gunman tries to behead a Thai labourer who has been shot in the stomach; unable to find a knife, he hacks away at the man's neck with a garden hoe. Other images show burned babies and children with their brains spilling from their heads. Several of the attackers proudly pose for photos next to their victims.

The barbarity sparked rage in Israel and abroad. There is broad support for a military campaign to topple Hamas in Gaza, which it has controlled since it ousted the Palestinian Authority ( PA ) in 2007. But there are also powerful voices urging caution—Joe Biden's most of all.

His fear that Israel is rushing into a war with no clear endgame is a valid one. The Israeli security establishment would like to see the PA , which governs parts of the occupied West Bank, also retake control in Gaza. But one senior official admits that no serious planning has been done. Mr Netanyahu even denied that such a plan exists.

Mr Biden also fears that the war will not stay in Gaza. On Israel's northern border with Lebanon, there have been daily exchanges of fire. Hizbullah, the Shia militia cum political party, has attacked Israeli towns and army posts with anti-tank missiles, and Israel has shelled and bombed southern Lebanon. Hizbullah admits that some 40 of its fighters have been killed (the real toll is probably higher).这是他们自2006年战争以来最持续的战斗，尽管它尚未超越泰特（Tit-Tat）轰炸。

叙利亚和伊拉克的民兵使用无人机来攻击美国基地，那里有两十多名士兵受伤。 10月19日，五角大楼说，一名美国驱逐舰，卡尼号号航空母舰，击落了导弹，从也门在红海上发射的无人机。美国认为他们的目标是以色列南部，这是赫斯斯（Houthis）的杰出战争， 这是伊朗支持的民兵。

危险的校准

所有这些升级都是很小的 - 伊朗想展示其代理人的范围，而不是将该地区陷入战争。但是它们很冒险。在以色列或黎巴嫩杀死许多人的罢工将足以破坏平衡。为了使这一可能性降低，以色列在北部撤离了大约二十个社区，其中包括Kiryat Shmona，这是一个在黎巴嫩边境附近有20,000多人的城市。随着居民向北逃走，黎巴嫩一方的村庄也清空了。

以色列也加强了它的边界：本月许多召集的预备役人员被送到了北，而不是南部。美国已经部署了两个飞机驾驶罢工团体，一个是地中海东部的罢工团体，另一个是向波斯湾。 10月21日，它表示将部署更多的爱国者防空营和THAAD反焊接导弹炮弹。另外有2,000名士兵正在待命，以进行部署。

以色列的评估是，这些增援部队阻止了真主的加强战斗。在战争内阁中发起先发制人的罢工的谈话已经下降。最近，石油市场似乎也更加乐观。布伦特原油的价格从哈马斯袭击之前的每桶85美元到10月19日的92美元，到了90美元以下。

随着国际谴责的增长， 每一次以色列战争都在观看时钟，并最终获得了支持。 1973年，美国敦促结束赎罪日战争的停火，尽管以色列部队正在进步。 2006年，它在以色列实现其在黎巴嫩的目标之前实行了停火。正如一位以色列官员所说，“我们的国际合法性窗口有限。”

加沙恐怖的场景意味着窗户已经关闭。联合国说该领土上有140万人流离失所。它的避难所被挤压到其容量的两倍半。 10月13日，以色列告诉北加沙北部的整个人口逃离南方。从那以后，成千上万的命令以另一种方式回去。他们认为，如果在任何地方没有安全的感觉，那比帐篷或拥挤的庇护所更好。

以色列拒绝允许任何物资越过边界，直到哈马斯释放其占领的所有人质为止。 10月21日，第一次艾滋病货车是一支由20辆载客，水和药品的卡车从埃及进入加沙的。随后还有几次交货。这只是该领土所需的一小部分（联合国说每天至少需要100辆卡车）。一家人每天都会减少一顿饭。人们诉诸于从井中喝咸水。援助人员说，不良的卫生事件导致了疮和腹泻病例，并担心更严重的疾病会传播。

自10月7日以来，没有燃料进入加沙。唯一的发电厂是离线的，以色列减少了通常提供的电力供应。世界卫生组织说，加沙的13家医院中有6家已经用完了燃料。大多数面包店的关闭是出于相同的原因。在那些仍在工作的人排队长达六个小时。以色列拒绝允许燃料运输。

阿拉伯国家希望立即停火。欧盟分裂了，但其顶级外交官乔塞普·博雷尔（Josep Borrell）呼吁“人道主义停顿”以允许更多的物资进入。英国总理Rishi Sunak也表示支持一个。美国仍然提供以色列坚定的支持，但不会无限期地提供支持。

然而，内塔尼亚胡先生面临着他坚硬的基地的压力，以证明他正在驾驶哈马斯，并承认拜登先生或人质的家人一直保持着他的手。取而代之的是，使用代理，他已经开始简要介绍军队还没有准备好进行地面战役。有人认为，以色列不应冒险生命，而应发动更具毁灭性的空袭，包括使用破坏炸弹炸弹来摧毁哈马斯的隧道网络。

陆军退缩了，说这已经“完全准备”入侵。以色列媒体上有一些丑陋但准确的头条新闻，关于内塔尼亚胡先生和他的国防部长Yoav Gallant之间的不和谐。内塔尼亚胡先生在三月份试图解雇加兰特先生，因为后者对政府削弱最高法院的计划提出了批评。在大规模的公共抗议活动之后，他被迫撤退。从那以后，两者之间一直在不信任，现在它阻碍了以色列的战争规划努力。

10月11日，一个反对党的领导人本尼·甘茨（Benny Gantz）和加迪·艾森科特（Gadi Eisenkot） - 前陆军酋长 - 加入了战争内阁。但是他们没有恢复统一。一位辩护官员说：“ [陆军]和情报界因未能检测到的袭击而受到严重打击。” “但是他们已经站起来了，现在只是在等待政府的明确想法。”

一般混乱

陆军的命令仍在摧毁哈马斯的军事能力并结束对加沙的控制。军队内部的一些人和更广泛的国防机构认为，更逐步的地面运动会更好。但是将军被告知要为广泛的进攻做准备。除非内阁给他们一个不同的时间表或不同的目标，否则他们无法更改该计划。内阁在抖动。

陆军局长赫兹·哈莱维将军已承认该军队未能防止大屠杀。以色列内部安全服务的Shin Bet主任Ronen Bar和军事情报部门负责人Aharon Haliva将军也是如此。期望这三个人做到这一点，并在战后辞职。大多数以色列人希望他们的总理承担类似的责任，但他没有。

取而代之的是，内塔尼亚胡（Netanyahu）大部分时间都花在政治顾问和简报记者中。他已经将自己的前将军和安全官员的影子柜与第二次猜测加兰特先生和军队组合在一起。内塔尼亚胡（Netanyahu）联盟的一位以色列议会成员说：“有许多人认为哈马斯不敢做这样的事情。” “显然，比比比其他所有人都更怪，但不要等他这么说。”

即使是一个充满活力的政府，也将难以在如此众多的竞争优先事项之间进行导航，而这些天，以色列几乎没有政府。 ■

10月24日，与加沙边界附近的Sraeli士兵感到惊讶，看到一个熟悉的人物访问了哈马斯袭击摧毁的基布兹姆。超东正教党SHAS的领导人Arye Deri是总理Binyamin Netanyahu联盟最大的党之一，他也参观了为加沙战争做准备的军事部队。一天前，德里先生泄露了与党员的会议细节，他说以色列国防军（ IDF ）“还没有准备好”，激怒了以色列的军事首领。

德里先生在政府中没有官方角色，也没有任何重大的军事经验。然而，总理邀请他以非正式的能力参加战争内阁的一些会议。他的资格是他是内塔尼亚胡先生的重要政治盟友。

通过其他方式，战争是政治，这场战争越来越政治化。尽管民意测验在以色列人在加沙地面攻势中表现出广泛的支持，但他们也表现出对内塔尼亚胡先生的支持。不到一年前，大约有40％支持他的利库德党的选民说他们会投票给其他人。一旦冲突结束，将呼吁全国调查委员会举行。

10月25日，以色列官员表示，他们同意推迟入侵加沙，以允许美国在该地区进行防空。但是，内塔尼亚胡先生的压力越来越大，他的右翼基地以证明他准备摧毁哈马斯。总理的代理人一直在向记者介绍，以色列将军们建议，更具毁灭性的空袭需要销毁更具毁灭性的空袭，而不是危害以色列士兵的生命，而不是危害以色列士兵的生命，而不是危害以色列士兵的生命，而不是危害以色列士兵的生命，需要销毁以色列的生命，而是需要更加毁灭性的空袭来销毁，那么总理并没有为销毁以色列的生命，而不是危害以色列的生命，就需要销毁以色列的生命，而不是危害以色列的生命，还需要更加毁灭的空气打击来销毁，而不是危害以色列的生命，就需要销毁以色列的生命哈马斯的隧道网络。实际上，这导致了IDF的愤怒回应。这也引起了以色列媒体上关于内塔尼亚胡先生和他的国防部长Yoav Gallant之间不和谐的丑陋和准确的挑战。

该政府内部的分裂并不是什么新鲜事。内塔尼亚胡三月份在公开批评政府削弱最高法院权力的计划后，试图解雇加兰特先生。面对大规模的公共抗议活动，总理被迫撤退。但是，从那时起，两者之间的不信任现在正在阻碍以色列的战争规划。与反对党之一的领导人本尼·甘茨（Benny Gantz）和加迪·艾森科特（Gadi Eisenkot）建立了“团结政府”，其中包括前IDF参谋长，也是战争内阁的一部分 - 未能实现任何实际的团结。

内塔尼亚胡与以色列将军的关系长期以来一直很紧张。他们对哈马斯在10月7日的袭击中的反应加剧了这种紧张。一位高级国防官员说：“以色列国防军和情报界因未能检测到哈马斯袭击而受到严重打击。” “但是他们已经站起来了，现在正在等待政府关于该怎么做的明确想法。”相比之下，以色列的政客尤其是其总理，似乎仍然在挣扎。

陆军的参谋长赫兹·哈莱维中将已经公开承认10月7日的失败，以色列的安全服务局的申恩·贝特（Shin Bet）董事和军事情报部门负责人阿哈伦·哈利瓦（Aharon Haliva）的负责人也是如此。 。一旦战争结束，所有人都应该辞职。不过，总理没有接受任何这种责任，而不是在10月25日模糊地说“只有战后”才会问“也是我的”。

内塔尼亚胡（Netanyahu）联盟的一位以色列议会成员说：“有许多人认为哈马斯不敢做这样的事情。” “显然，比比比其他所有人都更怪，但不要等他这么说。”取而代之的是，当他没有与他的战争内阁会面或欢迎外国领导人会议时，内塔尼亚胡先生最近几天都花了大部分时间与他的政治顾问和向记者介绍。他还组装了前将军和安全官员的影子柜，第二次猜测加兰特先生和以色列国防军的将军。

总理并不是唯一专注于政治的人。支持内塔尼亚胡先生的极右翼和超级宗教政党的联盟知道，这可能不会持续很长时间：公众的愤怒和另一次选举可能会扫除他们。但是他们渴望尽可能长时间地坚持自己的力量，并充分利用自己的力量。国家安全部长兼犹太人权力领导人伊塔马尔·本·吉尔（Itamar Ben-Gvir）表面上向平民展示了将武器交给平民，以防止进一步的恐怖袭击。但是他一直在试图在以色列犹太人和阿拉伯 - 以色列人之间施加紧张局势。至少目前，他还没有成功。 （他没有被明确包括在战争内阁中。）其他联盟伙伴已阻止努力获得现金，以帮助数千个以色列家庭被战争连根拔起，因为他们担心这笔钱会从资助自己社区的特殊利益的资金中转移出来。

所有的演讲都是在加沙战斗的下一阶段，而不是随后的战斗。以色列的安全机构宁愿看到巴勒斯坦权力机构，该机构在2007年的一场流血政变中被哈马斯罢免，返回并控制该地区。但是一位高级官员承认，这方面没有做任何计划。十多年来，内塔尼亚胡先生一直隔离并被忽视的加沙，认为它可以安全地溃烂。 10月7日的袭击证明了该政策的悲惨失败。他现在对战争的政治化，也不愿计划未来，这可能会使以色列更大。 ■

哈马斯战士在加沙地带的安全栅栏上蜂拥而至，炸死1400多人，绑架了220多人的几天后，杰拉尔德·R·福特（ US Gerald R. Ford军舰舰队。由Dwight D. Eisenhower US领导的第二个运营商罢工小组正航行到中东，大概是靠近伊朗。飞机和防空系统正在被派往该地区，也准备好部队。
